title: Corbin v. Kohler
description: This is a Workers' Compensation case.  The issues are trifurcated: (1) whether the plaintiff contracted silicosis at his workplace; (2) whether the plaintiff is totally and permanently disabled; and (3) whether the employer is entitled to a set-off for benefits paid to claimant under a salary continuation plan.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
James R. Corbin, Claimant, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Kohler Company, Self-Insured Employer, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3554
Heard September 12, 2002 â€“ Filed October 7, 2002

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Mary Lou Hill, of Greenville, for Appellant.
J. Mark Hayes, II, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 ANDERSON, J.:Â  Kohler Company appeals the decision 
  of the Circuit Court affirming an award of Workersâ€™ Compensation.Â  Kohler argues: 
  (1) the Circuit Court did not apply the correct standard of review; (2) the 
  record does not support the Circuit Courtâ€™s decision; and (3) the Circuit Court 
  erred in finding Kohler was not entitled to set off for payments it made to 
  Corbin under a salary continuation plan.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
James R. Corbin (Corbin) worked in the 
  casting department at Kohler Company in Spartanburg for forty-one years.Â  Corbin 
  testified that, during his career at Kohler, he was exposed to significant amounts 
  of silica dust.Â  In 1999, he first began having respiratory symptoms, including 
  a dry cough which progressed to some shortness of breath and loss of stamina.Â  
  Corbinâ€™s family physician referred him to Dr. Douglas Clark, a pulmonary specialist.Â  
  Additionally, he was seen by Dr. Mary Lou Applebaum, a pulmonary specialist 
  in the same office as Dr. Clark.Â  In August 1999, Dr. Applebaum removed Corbin 
  from work and advised him he had silicosis.Â Â Â Â Â  
Corbin filed a Form 50 seeking Workersâ€™ Compensation 
  benefits for the silicosis.Â  Kohler denied the compensability of his claim.Â  

Corbin was evaluated by several doctors 
  in connection with his illness, in addition to Drs. Applebaum and Clark.Â  Dr. 
  William Stewart reviewed Corbinâ€™s medical records and other factors to provide 
  a vocational and rehabilitation assessment.Â  Dr. Donald Schlueter examined the 
  records of Dr. Applebaum and her partners.Â  Drs. Kevin Kopera and Arden Levy 
  also evaluated Corbin.
 In his order, the Single Commissioner found that 
  Corbin sustained an occupational disease arising out of and in the course of 
  his employment at Kohler.Â  He found Corbinâ€™s occupational disease was silicosis 
  resulting from prolonged exposure to silica dust in the workplace and Corbin 
  was permanently and totally disabled as a result of his occupational disease.Â  
  The Commissioner denied Kohler credit for benefits paid to Corbin under his 
  salary continuation program, and ordered the payment of 500 weeks compensation 
  in addition to reimbursement and coverage of all medical, hospital, pharmaceutical, 
  and other expenses related to Corbinâ€™s occupational disease.Â  Kohler appealed 
  the order to the full Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.
The Commission upheld the Single Commissionerâ€™s 
  decision in its entirety.Â  Kohler appealed.Â  The Circuit Court affirmed the 
  findings of the Commission and dismissed the appeal.
ISSUES

  
  
    
       I.  
    
    
       
  Did the Circuit Court apply the correct standard of review in upholding the 
  decision of the Commission?
  
  
  
     II.   
  
  
     
  Does the record support the Circuit Courtâ€™s finding that the Commissionâ€™s decision 
  was supported by substantial evidence in the record as a whole?
  
  
  
     III.  
  
  
     
  Did the Circuit Court err in finding that Kohler was not entitled to a set off 
  from the Commissionâ€™s award to Corbin for compensation paid under the salary 
  continuation plan?
  
  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures 
  Act (APA) establishes the standard for judicial review of decisions of the Workersâ€™ 
  Compensation Commission.Â  Gibson v. Spartanburg School Dist. No. 3, 338 
  S.C. 510, 526 S.E.2d 725 (Ct. App. 2000); Hamilton v. Bob Bennett Ford, 
  336 S.C. 72, 518 S.E.2d 599 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  In an appeal from the Commission, 
  this Court may not substitute its judgment for that of the Commission as to 
  the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, but may reverse where the decision 
  is affected by an error of law.Â  Hamilton, 336 S.C. at 76, 518 S.E.2d 
  at 601.Â  The appellate courtâ€™s review is limited to deciding whether the Commissionâ€™s 
  decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error 
  of law.Â  Id.Â  The findings of an administrative agency are presumed correct 
  and will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  Hicks 
  v. Piedmont Cold Storage, 335 S.C. 46, 515 S.E.2d 532 (1999); Broughton 
  v. South of the Border, 336 S.C. 488, 520 S.E.2d 634 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  It 
  is not within our province to reverse findings of the Commission which are supported 
  by substantial evidence.Â  Hunter v. Patrick Constr. Co., 289 S.C. 46, 
  344 S.E.2d 613 (1986); Broughton, 336 S.C. at 496, 520 S.E.2d 637.Â  
Substantial evidence is not a mere scintilla 
  of evidence, nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but 
  is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable 
  minds to reach the conclusion the administrative agency reached in order to 
  justify its action.Â  Miller v. State Roofing Co., 312 S.C. 452, 441 S.E.2d 
  323 (1994); Muir v. C.R. Bard, Inc., 336 S.C. 266, 519 S.E.2d 583 (Ct. 
  App. 1999).Â  â€œIndeed, the possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions 
  from the evidence does not prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s findings from 
  being supported by substantial evidence.â€Â  Muir, 336 S.C. at 282, 519 
  S.E.2d at 591.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Standard of Review
Kohler contends the Circuit Court failed 
  to apply the correct standard of judicial review in upholding the decision of 
  the Commission.Â  We disagree.
At the hearing before the Circuit Court, the following 
  colloquy occurred:
THE COURT: All right.Â  Iâ€™m looking at Page 12 of the order.Â  
  And it alleged â€“ I mean, itâ€™s based on claimantâ€™s functional limitations and 
  report of Dr. William Stewart, it is clear that claimant is and will be permanently 
  and totally disabled.Â  Where can I find Dr. Stewartâ€™s â€“ this is it right here.Â  
  William Stewart?
MS. HILL: Yes.Â  Dr. Stewart talks about disability.Â  But 
  Dr. Stewart does not connect the disability to silicosis.Â  And the finding on 
  functional limitation, there is no functional limitation other than heâ€™s got 
  to stay out of dust.
THE COURT: Well, both of you are aware Iâ€™ve got to see if 
  there is any evidence, basically.
MS. HILL: I understand, Your Honor.
  . . . 
THE COURT: [Dr. Stewart] says he concluded his prognosis 
  was successful vocational rehabilitation to some kind of lighter work job be 
  considered very poor to nonexistent.Â  If we were to assume he could, in fact, 
  return to some kind of alternative work, he has concluded â€“ and then he goes 
  into that he could only earn $7.50 an hour.Â  Is that not enough evidence for 
  the â€“ coupled with what they call functional limitations?Â  Isnâ€™t that some evidence 
  on which they could base their opinion?
MS. HILL: This is evidence by a vocational expert that, in 
  his opinion, he is going to have a hard time finding a job with his limitation 
  of not being able to work in dust, strong fumes, or odors.Â  But nowhere in here 
  does he say that his disability is caused by the occupational disease of silicosis.Â  
  And thatâ€™s my point.Â  There is no evidence on the causal connection between 
  this manâ€™s impairment, even if he has some, even if he has silicosis, and his 
  disability.Â 
THE COURT: Well, I thought Dr. Applebaum said he did have 
  silicosis.
MS. HILL: He â€“ yes, she certainly did.
THE COURT: Well, isnâ€™t that enough?Â  You donâ€™t have to have 
  15 doctors.Â  Once the Workers Comp. Commission has any evidence that he had 
  silicosis -- and Dr. Applebaum says he does -- isnâ€™t that -- doesnâ€™t that jump 
  the hurdle?
MS. HILL: She said he had silicosis.Â  She put no functional 
  limitations on him other than he canâ€™t work where itâ€™s real dusty.
THE COURT:Â  Well, letâ€™s take it one step at the time.Â  Doesnâ€™t 
  that get him over the first hurdle, though?Â  Doesnâ€™t that put him â€“ having silicosis?
MS. HILL: Yes.
THE COURT:Â  And doesnâ€™t that also put it as a result of inhaling 
  silica while employed at Kohler Company, as she states in so many word[s]?
MS. HILL:Â  Yes, but she never states that it resulted in 
  a disability that prevented him from working.
THE COURT: I understand that.Â  Iâ€™m just taking it one step 
  at a time.
MS. HILL: Okay.
THE COURT: So she says heâ€™s got silicosis and that he has 
  residual pulmonary condition.
MS. HILL: Thatâ€™s right.Â  But she also states, in an earlier 
  report, that his pulmonary functioning was normal.Â  He just canâ€™t work where 
  itâ€™s dusty.
THE COURT: Well, so, she said two different things.Â  That 
  goes to weight; does it not?Â  Why should I believe the first one and not the 
  second?Â  And â€“ instead of the Commission believing one as opposed to the other?Â  
  When you got somebody saying two things, you can either believe the first, second, 
  or somewhere in between.
MS. HILL: Well, when she says residual . . .
THE COURT: . . . pulmonary.
MS. HILL: All right.Â  I â€“ Iâ€™m . . .
THE COURT: Letâ€™s see.Â  In my opinion, within a reasonable 
  degree of certainty, he has a silicosis, condition as a result of exposure.Â  
  It is my opinion, within a reasonable degree of medical certainty, that Mr. 
  Corbin suffers from a significant pulmonary condition, referred to as silicosis.Â  
  Thatâ€™s what she says heâ€™s got.Â  And thatâ€™s what she says, to a reasonable degree 
  of medical certainty, creates a significant pulmonary condition.Â  She said that, 
  not Dr. Applebaum.Â  I donâ€™t know whether itâ€™s true or not.Â  But I canâ€™t weigh 
  the evidence; Iâ€™ve got to see if there is any.Â  To me the question becomes whether 
  or not he has silicosis and he got it at Kohler Company.Â  So the question becomes, 
  whether or not, based on that and Dr. Stewartâ€™s report, that is â€“ jumps the 
  hurdle of some evidence.Â  And Iâ€™m going to find that it does.Â  Iâ€™m going to 
  dismiss the appeal.
  . . .
THE COURT: As I see it, Iâ€™ve got a very little narrow thing 
  I can look at.Â  And once that little hurdle is jumped, I canâ€™t say, Well, Iâ€™d 
  have found different, or anything like that.Â  Once they get the door open just 
  a crack, thatâ€™s all it takes.Â  That may be all thatâ€™s here but thatâ€™s all it 
  takes.Â  
Kohler asserts the trial judgeâ€™s 
  statements reflect his misunderstanding of the standard of review.Â  Kohler maintains 
  the Circuit Court reviewed the Commissionâ€™s decision based on a â€œcracked doorâ€ 
  standard of review in which a mere scintilla of evidence would be sufficient 
  to sustain the decision of the Commission.Â  This argument has no merit because 
  the statements by the judge were merely contemporaneous colloquy.Â  The judge 
  and the lawyers were talking in the course of working through the attorneysâ€™ 
  arguments.Â  The judgeâ€™s final written order represents the decision of the court.
â€œNo order is final until it is written 
  and entered.â€Â  First Union Natâ€™l Bank v. Hitman, Inc., 306 S.C. 327, 
  329, 411 S.E.2d 681, 682 (Ct. App. 1991), affâ€™d, 308 S.C. 421, 418 S.E.2d 
  545 (1992) (citing Rule 58(a), SCRCP).Â  See also Case v. Case, 
  243 S.C. 447, 134 S.E.2d 394 (1964) (judgments in general are not final until 
  written and entered); Bayne v. Bass, 302 S.C. 208, 394 S.E.2d 726 (Ct. 
  App. 1990) (divorce decree is not final until written and recorded).Â  â€œUntil 
  written and entered, the trial judge retains discretion to change his mind and 
  amend his oral ruling accordingly.â€Â  Ford v. State Ethics Commâ€™n, 344 
  S.C. 642, 646, 545 S.E.2d 821, 823 (2001); First Union Natâ€™l Bank, 306 
  S.C. at 329, 411 S.E.2d at 682.Â  See also Case v. Case, 243 S.C. 
  at 451, 134 S.E.2d at 396 (holding even if the trial judge made oral ruling 
  in favor of one party, such pronouncement is not a final ruling on the merits 
  nor is it binding on the parties until it has been reduced to writing, signed 
  by the judge, and delivered for recordation).
â€œIt is well settled that a judge is not 
  bound by a prior oral ruling and may issue a written order which is in conflict 
  with the oral ruling.â€Â  Badeaux v. Davis, 337 S.C. 195, 204, 522 S.E.2d 
  835, 839 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  See also Owens v. Magill, 308 S.C. 
  556, 419 S.E.2d 786 (1992) (ruling judge was not bound by prior oral ruling 
  and could issue written order which conflicted with prior oral ruling).Â  â€œTo 
  the extent the written order may conflict with the prior oral ruling, the written 
  order controls.â€Â  Parag v. Baby Boy Lovin, 333 S.C. 221, 226, 508 S.E.2d 
  590, 592 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  â€œThe written order is the trial judgeâ€™s final order 
  and as such constitutes the final judgment of the court.Â  The final written 
  order contains the binding instructions which are to be followed by the parties.â€Â  
  Ford, 344 S.C. at 646, 545 S.E.2d at 823 (citing Rule 58, SCRCP).   
The judgeâ€™s final order reads:

  The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act, S.C. Code 
  Ann. Section 1-23-310, et. seq., establishes the â€œsubstantial evidenceâ€ rule 
  as the standard for judicial review of a decision of an administrative agency.Â  
  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 276 S.E.2d 304 (1981).Â  On an appeal 
  from the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission, the court may not substitute its 
  judgment for that of the Commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions 
  of fact, but may reverse where the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  
  Stephen v. Avins Construction Company, 324 S.C. 334, 478 S.E.2d 74 (Ct. 
  App. 1996).Â  Also see Lyles v. Quantum Chemical Company, 315 S.C. 440, 
  434 S.E.2d 292 (Ct. App. 1993).

This paragraph accurately states the â€œsubstantial 
  evidenceâ€ standard of review which the judge applied in his final written order.Â  
  Regardless of the colloquy during the hearing, the final written order correctly 
  articulated the â€œsubstantial evidenceâ€ standard.Â  Thus, we find no error.
II.Â  Substantial Evidence to Support the Decision of the Commission
Kohler argues the record does not support 
  a finding that the Commissionâ€™s decision was supported by the substantial evidence 
  in the record as a whole.Â  We disagree.
Beginning in April 1999, Corbin was seen by Dr. 
  Applebaum.Â  By August of 1999, Dr. Applebaum had removed Corbin from work and 
  diagnosed him with silicosis.Â  Corbin continued in her care through March 2000, 
  when Dr. Applebaum found he had reached â€œmaximum medical improvement.â€Â  Dr. 
  Applebaumâ€™s memorandum dated March 17, 2000 provided:

Please be advised that the undersigned is the treating physician 
  for James R. Corbin.Â  A complete copy of my medical records concerning Mr. Corbin 
  is attached.Â  
Based on the history presented, my examination, and x-ray 
  and other diagnostic evaluations, it is my opinion within a reasonable degree 
  of medical certainty that Mr. Corbin suffers from a significant pulmonary condition 
  referred to as silicosis.Â  Based on my examination, treatment records, x-ray 
  and diagnostic evaluations, the history presented, and my review of certain 
  Industrial Hygiene Sampling Results, it is my opinion within a reasonable degree 
  of medical certainty that Mr. Corbinâ€™s silicosis condition was most probably 
  the result of exposure to respirable silica (Crystalline Quartz) while employed 
  at the Kohler Company, in Spartanburg, South Carolina.
I have been treating Mr. Corbin since April of 1999.Â  I have 
  continued to treat him since August 30, 1999 when I advised that he should leave 
  his work environment at Kohler.Â  It is my opinion that he has now reached maximum 
  medical improvement concerning his condition.Â  However, it is further my opinion 
  that it is medically necessary that he avoid any further exposure to respirable 
  silica dust in any fashion.Â  It is further my opinion that due to his residual 
  pulmonary condition, he will be unable to work in any environment that would 
  result in pulmonary exposure to dust, strong fumes or odors, or extreme hot 
  or cold temperatures.Â  

Dr. William W. Stewart, a vocational 
  rehabilitation specialist, evaluated Corbin.Â  He did not meet with Corbin personally, 
  but he reviewed the records of Dr. Applebaum and Dr. Douglas Clark.Â  He analyzed 
  vocational and occupational factors, labor market access, Corbinâ€™s ability to 
  earn, and his earning capacity.Â  His vocational and rehabilitation assessment 
  stated in pertinent part:

IMPRESSIONS AND CONCLUSIONS
Based on Mr. Corbinâ€™s evaluation it is concluded that he 
  is a person who sustained significant work-related injury, or injuries, to his 
  lungs, with continuing problems and limitations, and work restrictions that 
  will prevent him from ever being able to return to the kind of work he had normally 
  performed in the past.Â  And, after considering all vocational/occupational factors 
  relating to Mr. Corbin, including his advanced/retirement age, and all medical/pulmonary 
  factors, including his inability to return to the kind of work he had normally 
  performed over the past 41 years, it is concluded that his prognosis for successful 
  vocational rehabilitation to some kind of lighter, alternative worker job has 
  to be considered very poor to non-existent.
If it were assumed that he could, in fact, return to some 
  kind of alternative work, it is concluded that Mr. Corbinâ€™s ability to earn 
  has been reduced to no more than approximately $7.50 per hour because of his 
  injuries, continuing problems and limitations, and his permanent work restrictions.Â  


Corbin testified there was silica 
  dust at Kohler.Â  He provided a photo which showed dust accumulation in his office.Â  
  He declared his â€œhealth has been excellent before this last illness.â€Â  He stated 
  that, after having trouble breathing, his family doctor referred him to â€œa set 
  of pulmonary doctors.â€Â  Corbin explained that he saw Dr. Applebaum and did not 
  return to work after she diagnosed him with silicosis.
In addition to the materials and 
  testimony of Dr. Applebaum, Dr. Stewart, and Corbin, other evidence was presented 
  relating to Corbinâ€™s illness.Â  Dr. Arden Levy, of Foothill Allergy and Asthma 
  Associates, saw Corbin on one occasion.Â  In his report, Dr. Levy diagnosed Corbin 
  with possible bronchial asthma and rhinosinusitis, which may have contributed 
  to his cough. Â Dr. Donald Schlueter did not see Corbin but reviewed some 
  of the records of Dr. Applebaum and her partners.Â  Dr. Schlueter expressed his 
  opinion â€œto a reasonable degree of medical certainty that Mr. Corbinâ€™s asthma 
  was not caused by any occupational exposure at Kohler Company.â€ Dr. Kevin Kopera 
  declared that he did not believe Corbin had silicosis, though he conceded on 
  cross-examination he could not exclude silicosis as a diagnosis.Â  Dr. Kopera 
  was not a pulmonologist.
 Expert medical testimony is designed 
  to aid the Commission in coming to the correct conclusion.Â  Tiller v. National 
  Health Care Ctr., 334 S.C. 333,Â  513 S.E.2d 843 (1999).Â  Therefore, the 
  Commission determines the weight and credit to be given to the expert testimony.Â  
  Id.Â  Once admitted, expert testimony is to be considered just like any 
  other testimony.Â  Id.; Smith v. Southern Builders, 202 S.C. 88, 
  24 S.E.2d 109 (1943).
Dr. Applebaum saw Corbin more 
  than any other doctor.Â  She is a pulmonologist who specializes in the very type 
  of condition Corbin sustained in his workplace.Â  Dr. Schlueter never examined 
  Corbin personally but instead reviewed the records of other doctors.Â  Dr. 
  Kopera performed an evaluation, but he is not a pulmonologist.Â  Dr. Levy 
  saw Corbin only one time.Â  The evidence provided by Dr. Applebaum was entitled 
  to greater weight than that of the other expert medical testimony, as she saw 
  Corbin more and was a specialist in pulmonology.
In our opinion, substantial evidence 
  supports the Commissionâ€™s finding that Corbin suffered from silicosis arising 
  out of and in the course of his employment at Kohler.Â  This evidence includes 
  the letters of Drs. Applebaum and Stewart, as well as Corbinâ€™s own testimony.Â  
  Because there was substantial evidence in the record to support the decision 
  of the Commission, there was no error by the Circuit Court in affirming the 
  Commissionâ€™s order.
III.Â  Set Off of Award
Kohler claims the Circuit Court 
  erred in finding it was not entitled to a set off from the Commissionâ€™s award 
  for compensation paid to Corbin under his salary continuation plan.Â  We disagree.Â  

Under the salary continuation plan, beginning 
  in August 1999, Kohler paid 100% of Corbinâ€™s base salary for the first three 
  months of his disability and 80% for the following three months, thus compensating 
  Corbin for a total of 26 weeks.Â  Kohlerâ€™s pay protection program brochure states: 
  â€œ[y]ouâ€™re eligible to participate in the Pay Protection Program if youâ€™re an 
  active full-time exempt associate.â€Â  Kohler paid the cost of each employeeâ€™s 
  pay protection program.Â  In the materials relating to the program, there was 
  no mention of Workersâ€™ Compensation.Â  Significantly, there was a section explaining 
  â€œwhen benefits are not paid,â€ and Workersâ€™ Compensation is not mentioned in 
  connection with this list.
South Carolina Code Ann. section 42-9-210 
  provides:

  Any payments made by an employer to an injured employee 
  during the period of his disability, or to his dependents, which by the terms 
  of this Title were not due and payable when made may, subject to the approval 
  of the Commission, be deducted from the amount to be paid as compensation; provided, 
  that in the case of disability such deductions shall be made by shortening the 
  period during which compensation must be paid and not by reducing the amount 
  of the weekly payment.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-210 (1985).
â€œThe approval of the Commission for such 
  deduction is required by Â§ 42-9-210.â€Â  Muir v. C.R. Bard, Inc., 336 S.C. 
  266, 298, 519 S.E.2d 583, 599 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  â€œIn order for payments to be 
  deductible, they must have been made with reference to liability under the provisions 
  of the Act and intended to be in lieu of compensation.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œSince 
  only those payments are deductible which are made in contemplation of the legal 
  obligation of the employer to pay compensation to a disabled employee, the intent 
  with which such payments are made becomes important.â€Â  Id. (citing Brittle 
  v. Raybestos-Manhattan, Inc., 241 S.C. 255, 258, 127 S.E.2d 884, 885 (1962)).Â  

The payments Corbin received were from a compensation 
  plan which was set up internally at Kohler.Â  The intent of the plan was not 
  connected to Workersâ€™ Compensation benefits.Â  Rather, it was a benefit Kohler 
  provided to certain employees who became disabled.Â  We find no evidence in the 
  record that the payments were made with reference to liability under the Workersâ€™ 
  Compensation Act or in lieu of compensation.Â  We rule Kohler was not entitled 
  to a credit for the payments.
CONCLUSION
 Accordingly, based on the foregoing reasons, 
  the decision of the Circuit Court is
AFFIRMED.
CONNOR and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

 THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Kevin Cowan & Jimmy Blanding, Appellants,
      
    
  

  v.

  
    

Allstate Insurance Company, Respondent.

    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3555
Submitted September 9, 2002 â€“ Filed October 7, 2002

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Samuel D. Harms,Â  of Greenville, for appellants.
Robert D. Moseley, Jr., of Greenville, for respondent.
      
    
  


STILWELL, J.:Â  Kevin Cowan and 
  Jimmy Blanding (collectively Appellants) brought this declaratory judgment action 
  against Allstate Insurance Company to recover damages awarded by default against 
  Allstateâ€™s insured.Â  The circuit court ruled Allstate could assert its insuredâ€™s 
  failure to comply with the cooperation clause of the insurance policy and deny 
  coverage when it lacked actual knowledge of the lawsuit.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
Allstate issued the insurance policy to its named 
  insured, Charles A. Griffis, who was the owner of the vehicle involved in the 
  accident.Â  Stacy Johnson was operating Griffisâ€™ automobile with his permission 
  at the time of the accident.Â  Although Appellantsâ€™ counsel sent a letter of 
  representation to Allstate, they did not send a courtesy copy of the summons 
  and complaint, nor otherwise provide any notice that the lawsuit, which only 
  named Johnson as the defendant, had been filed and served.Â  Johnson did not 
  forward the summons and complaint to Allstate and did not file an answer.Â  Allstateâ€™s 
  first notice of the existence of a lawsuit was when Appellantsâ€™ counsel forwarded 
  a copy of the order awarding damages following the entry of default. Â Allstateâ€™s 
  motion on behalf of Johnson under Rule 60(b), SCRCP to be relieved of the judgment 
  was denied.Â  
Appellants then brought this declaratory judgment 
  action against Allstate to collect the judgment entered against its insured 
  based on coverage provided by the insurance policy.Â  On cross motions for summary 
  judgment, the circuit court held that Allstate could assert its insuredâ€™s failure 
  to comply with the cooperation clause to deny coverage when it lacked actual 
  knowledge of the lawsuit.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The sole issue on appeal is whether S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-142(B) (1997) overturned this courtâ€™s holding in Shores 
  v. Weaver, 315 S.C. 347, 433 S.E.2d 913 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  We hold that the 
  statutory language modified Shores, and affirm the circuit court.
In Shores, this court found that 
  a violation of the cooperation clause of an insurance contract providing the 
  statutory minimum amount of automobile liability insurance cannot prevent recovery 
  by an innocent victim.Â  Id. at 355, 433 S.E.2d at 917.Â  This court stated:Â  


â€œFurthermore, it appears to us that to allow the insuredâ€™s 
  failure to give notice of the accident to prevent the injured personâ€™s recovery 
  would be to practically nullify the statute by making the enforcement of the 
  rights of the person intended to be protected dependent upon the acts of the 
  very person who caused the injury.â€ 

Id. at 354, 433 S.E.2d at 916 (quoting Ott 
  v. Am. Fid. & Cas. Co, 161 S.C. 314, 319, 159 S.E.2d 635, 637 (1931).Â  
  This court went on to hold:

In conclusion, we hold, as a matter of public policy, the 
  minimum limits automobile liability insurance policy involved in this case was 
  not defeated or voided by [the insuredâ€™s] failure to comply with policy notice 
  provisions after the accident resulting in [the victimâ€™s] injuries, because 
  the coverage was mandated by the legislature to protect innocent third parties. 
  . . .

Id. at 356, 433 S.E.2d at 917.

Section 38-77-142(B) provides in pertinent part:
If an insurer has actual notice of a motion for judgment 
  or complaint having been served on an insured, the mere failure of the insured 
  to turn the motion or complaint over to the insurer may not be a defense to 
  the insurer, nor void the endorsement or provision, nor in any way relieve the 
  insurer of its obligations to the insured, provided the insured otherwise cooperates 
  and in no way prejudices the insurer.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-142(B) (Rev. 2002) (1997 
  Act No. 154, Â§ 11, eff. Mar. 1, 1999).Â  
Appellants argue Shores is still controlling precedent 
  because USAA v. Markosky, the progeny of Shores, continued to 
  apply it after the effective date of Â§ 38-77-142(B).Â  USAA v. Markosky, 
  340 S.C. 223, 530 S.E.2d 660 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Their reliance is misplaced.Â  
  Markosky did not apply this statute.Â  While it is true Markosky 
  was decided after the effective date of the statute, the accident occurred before 
  its effective date, and this court applied the Shores law. Therefore, 
  Markosky cannot be read to hold that Shores survives the statute.Â  
  Appellants then reason section 38-77-142(B) expanded Markosky by rendering 
  the insurer liable for the full amount of a judgment, rather than only the minimum 
  limits, if the insurer has notice of the lawsuit.Â  However, as Allstate aptly 
  notes, the statute could not have been intended to expand Markosky because 
  it was enacted in 1997, before Markosky was decided, though it did not 
  take effect until 1999.
The cardinal rule of statutory construction is 
  for the court to ascertain and effectuate the intent of the legislature.Â  Mid-State 
  Auto Auction of Lexington, Inc. v. Altman, 324 S.C. 65, 69, 476 S.E.2d 690, 
  692 (1996).Â  â€œIn interpreting a statute, words must be given their plain and 
  ordinary meaning without resorting to subtle or forced construction to limit 
  or expand the statuteâ€™s operation.â€Â  Rowe v. Hyatt, 321 S.C. 366, 369, 
  468 S.E.2d 649, 650 (1996).Â  â€œStatutes, as a whole, must receive practical, 
  reasonable, and fair interpretation, consonant with the purpose, design, and 
  policy of lawmakers.â€Â  TNS Mills, Inc. v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Revenue, 331 
  S.C. 611, 624, 503 S.E.2d 471, 478 (1998).Â  â€œIf a statuteâ€™s language is plain 
  and unambiguous and conveys a clear and definite meaning, there is no occasion 
  for employing rules of statutory interpretation and the court has no right to 
  look for or impose another meaning.â€Â  Miller v. Doe, 312 S.C. 444, 447, 
  441 S.E.2d 319, 321 (1994).Â  
The court must presume the legislature did not 
  intend a futile act, but rather intended its statutes to accomplish something.Â  
  See State ex rel. McLeod v. Montgomery, 244 S.C. 308, 314, 
  136 S.E.2d 778, 782 (1964).Â  â€œFinally, there is a basic presumption that the 
  legislature has knowledge of previous legislation as well as of judicial decisions 
  construing that legislation when later statutes are enacted concerning related 
  subjects.â€Â  Whitner v. State, 328 S.C. 1, 6, 492 S.E.2d 777, 779 (1997).
We find Section 38-77-142(B) is aimed at addressing 
  the concerns stated by this court in Shores, while also addressing some 
  concerns raised by our decision.Â  In Shores, this court concentrated 
  on the unfairness to the innocent victim in having to rely on the insured to 
  forward the complaint to the insurance company and otherwise cooperating with 
  the insurer prior to the insurer having a responsibility to provide coverage.Â  
  The statute specifically addresses this courtâ€™s concern by allowing the injured 
  party to provide notice of the lawsuit to the insurer and to no longer have 
  to rely on the injured party to provide the notice.Â  However, the statute also 
  removes the concern that insurers had to pay default judgments, as in this case, 
  where the insurer had no opportunity to participate in discovery or present 
  a defense.
As the trial court noted, â€œ[t]his interpretation 
  allows Plaintiffs the ability to avoid the effects of this section by informing 
  the carrier of the suit by sending a filed courtesy copy of the complaint, which 
  should encourage the open exchange of information and discourage default â€˜trapsâ€™ 
  where the insured is not represented by counsel.â€Â  The alternative is to render 
  meaningless the cooperation clause contained in virtually every policy of automobile 
  liability insurance.
Although the statutory language is couched in terms 
  which address the opposite of the situation in this case, we find the statute 
  is unambiguous and clearly states the insurer cannot enforce a cooperation clause 
  when it has actual knowledge and its insured otherwise cooperates and does nothing 
  to prejudice the insurerâ€™s interest.Â  By clear implication the reverse of that 
  proposition must, of necessity, apply.Â  The statute specifically includes the 
  conditions upon which the insurer may not enforce the cooperation clause.Â  When 
  the legislature spells out the specific conditions an insurer may not 
  rely upon to deny coverage or escape liability, then, a fortiori, the 
  legislature intended that the absence of those conditions may be relied upon 
  to provide a viable defense.Â  Therefore, consistent with rules of statutory 
  construction, we find the legislature intended to allow an insurer to enforce 
  its cooperation clause if neither the insured nor the innocent victim provided 
  the insurer with notice of the lawsuit.Â  See Hodges v. Rainey, 
  341 S.C. 79, 86, 533 S.E.2d 578, 582 (2000) (â€œThe canon of construction â€˜expressio 
  unius est exclusio alteriusâ€™ or â€˜inclusio unius est exclusio alteriusâ€™ 
  holds that â€˜to express or include one thing implies the exclusion of another, 
  or of the alternative.â€™â€).
Additionally, under the system established in Shores, 
  attorneys for the injured third party had no incentive to inform the insurer 
  of the lawsuit.Â  However, in addition to being zealous advocates on behalf of 
  their clients, members of the bar are also officers of the court.Â  The Canons 
  of Professional Ethics, the predecessor to the Rules of Professional Conduct, 
  â€œprohibit an attorney from engaging in practices that bring the courts or the 
  legal profession into disrepute.â€Â  Norris v. Alexander, 246 S.C. 14, 
  19, 142 S.E.2d 214, 217-18 (1965).Â  Activities undertaken for the purpose of 
  evading the full and fair litigation of a case on its merits do not promote 
  the essential goals upon which the Rules of Professional Conduct rest. 
Finally, the primary policy undergirding 
  the Shores holding has also been changed by statute.Â  Our holding in 
  Shores was premised on the mandatory minimum limits required by statute, 
  which could not be defeated by contract.Â  The same act containing Section 38-77-142(B) 
  also contained the provision codified at Section 56-10-510.Â  Under that section, 
  South Carolina allows a person to be uninsured by paying a fee and registering 
  with the Division of Motor Vehicles.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-10-510 (Supp. 2001).Â  
  Thus, South Carolina is no longer a mandatory insurance state, the critical 
  difference being that such policies are rendered voluntary.Â  â€œ[I]nsurers have 
  the right to limit their liability and to impose whatever conditions they desire 
  upon an insured, provided they are not in contravention of some statutory inhibition 
  or public policy.â€Â  Penn. Natâ€™l Mut. Cas. Ins. Co. v. Parker, 282 S.C. 
  546, 550-51, 320 S.E.2d 458, 461 (Ct. App. 1984) (citations omitted); see 
  also USAA v. Markosky, 340 S.C. 223, 226, 530 S.E.2d 660, 662 (Ct. 
  App. 2000).Â  
CONCLUSION
We hold section 38-77-142(B) is unambiguous and 
  was clearly intended by the legislature to address the situation presented in 
  Shores.Â  We find the trial courtâ€™s interpretation promotes the â€œtruth-seekingâ€ 
  function of the courts and allows for an open process aimed at a full examination 
  of all relevant facts.Â  Thus, we conclude the interpretation of section 38-77-142(B) 
  offered by the trial courtâ€”that an insurer who has no actual notice of a complaint 
  or motion for judgment having been served on an insured and with whom the insured 
  fails to cooperate to the prejudice of the insurer can rely on its cooperation 
  clause as a defense to deny a claimâ€”is the correct construction of the legislative 
  intent.
AFFIRMED.
CONNOR and ANDERSON, JJ., concur.

    Rule 215, SCACR.

THE 
  STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In 
  The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Richard E. Lee,       
Respondent/Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Thermal Engineering Corporation 
        and Willie Best,        Appellants/Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Alexander S. Macaulay, 
  Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3556Â Â 
Heard June 5, 2002 â€“ Filed October 28, 2002 

AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
W. Duvall Spruill, of Columbia; 
  for Appellant-Respondent(s)
Edwin Russell Jeter, of Columbia; 
  Richard J. Morgan, of Columbia; for Respondent-Appellant(s)
      
    
  

CURETON, J.:Â  Richard 
  E. Lee sued Thermal Engineering Corp. and its founder, Willie Best (collectively, 
  â€œThermalâ€), asserting claims for breach of contract and violation of the Payment 
  of Post-Termination Claims to Sales Representatives Act, S. C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-65-10 
  to â€“80 (Supp. 2001). Lee also sought punitive damages and attorney fees.Â  Following 
  a bench trial, the court granted judgment to Lee.Â  In a separate order, the 
  court awarded Lee attorney feesÂ  and prejudgment interest, but denied Leeâ€™s 
  request for punitive damages.Â  Both Thermal and Lee appeal.Â  We affirm in part 
  and reverse in part.
FACTS
Thermal 
  manufactures curing ovens, paint booths and control panels that operate manufacturing 
  equipment.Â  On October 5, 1987, Thermal entered into a written agreement with 
  Lee to serve as its sales representative in the Southeastern United States.
The agreement, 
  which was to run from year to year, provided that Lee was to be paid on a commission 
  basis for any orders accepted by Thermal.Â  Either party could terminate the 
  relationship upon six months written notice;Â  however, the agreement would remain 
  in force for six months after notice of termination.Â  Upon termination of the 
  contract, Lee was entitled to commissions for accounts he generated for a period 
  of eight months after the termination.Â  If an order was received from one of 
  Leeâ€™s customers during the eight months after termination then an additional 
  eight-month period would be in effect from the order date and would continue 
  in effect so long as orders were received during the eight-month interval.
On March 
  29, 1995, Thermal sent Lee notice of termination of the contract.Â  Lee reminded 
  Thermal of the six-month notice provision in their contract and requested an 
  accurate accounting of any commissions that might be due during the notice period.
Thermal disputed the application 
  of the notice provision and advised Lee that the March 29th letter 
  had declared their contract to be at an end. Thermal further advised Lee that 
  if he was already working on any particular projects that â€œThermal [was] willing 
  to work with [him] on a case-by-case basis so that those efforts wonâ€™t be wasted.â€Â  
  On November 9, 1995, after a demand from Leeâ€™s attorney, Thermal paid Lee $7098.42 
  for the undisputed, pre-termination commissions earned prior to March 29, 1995.
Lee filed this action against 
  Thermal seeking the balance of his post-termination commissions, plus punitive 
  damages and attorney fees.Â  The trial court awarded Lee a judgment of $58,465.64 
  for all the unpaid commissions in accordance with the notice provisions of the 
  contract.Â  The courtâ€™s order further provided Lee was entitled to reasonable 
  attorney fees and instructed him to submit an affidavit of attorney fees within 
  fifteen days of receipt of the order.Â  Following a hearing, the court awarded 
  Lee pre-judgment interest of $16,901.61 and attorney fees of $25,122.Â  This 
  appeal follows.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Thermalâ€™s 
  Appeal
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Oral Amendment of Contract
Thermal asserts the trial court committed reversible 
  error in ruling the contract was orally amended because Lee never asserted in 
  his pleadings that the written contract was modified.Â  We believe the question 
  of whether or not the contract was orally amended was presented to the trial 
  court.
Initially, we discuss Thermalâ€™s 
  argument that Leeâ€™s pleadings make no claim that the contract was orally amended 
  to include â€œengineeredâ€ products within its terms.Â  Thermal argues that clearly 
  the complaint bases Leeâ€™s right to recover on the written contract and that 
  Lee never made a motion to amend his pleadings to assert a right to recover 
  based on an oral modification.Â  Notwithstanding such failures, we conclude Leeâ€™s 
  pleadings should not preclude recovery in this case.Â  First, we note that Thermal 
  consistently asserted during trial that Lee was not entitled to recover because 
  the commissions he claimed were either not based on sales personally made by 
  him or that the sales were not of â€œpre-engineeredâ€ products.Â  Thermal never 
  asserted during trial that the pleadings limited Leeâ€™s recovery to commissions 
  from the sale of pre-engineered products only.Â  Having failed to object to the 
  courtâ€™s consideration of Leeâ€™s entitlement to commissions based on Leeâ€™s failure 
  to plead a modification of the Parties agreement, Thermal is considered to have 
  tried the issue by consent.Â  See Simmons v. Tuomey Regâ€™l Med. 
  Ctr., 330 S.C. 115, 125 n.2, 498 S.E.2d 408, 413 n.2 (Ct. App. 1998) (an 
  issue not expressly mentioned in the complaint but tried without objection and 
  incorporated in the trial courtâ€™s order is tried by consent according to Rule 
  15 SCRCP);Â  McCurry v. Keith, 325 S.C. 441, 447, 481 S.E. 2d 166, 169 
  (Ct. App. 1997) (issues tried by consent will be treated as if raised in the 
  pleadings).
Secondly, even if the record 
  on appeal could be interpreted to show Thermal raised the oral modification 
  issue at trial, the issue must be both presented to and ruled upon by the trial 
  court before it will be considered on appeal.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. 
  Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998)(â€œIt is axiomatic that 
  an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised 
  to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€);Â  
  First Union Natâ€™l Bank of S.C. v. Soden, 333 S.C. 554, 566, 511 S.E.2d 
  372, 378 (Ct. App. 1998) (â€œIt is a fundamental rule of law that an appellate 
  court will affirm a ruling by a lower court if the offended party does not challenge 
  that ruling.â€).
We now move to Thermalâ€™s 
  claim that the evidence does not support the trial courtâ€™s holding that the 
  contract in issue was orally amended.Â  â€œIt is true that a simple contract completely 
  reduced to writing cannot be changed or modified by parol evidence of what was 
  said or done by the parties at the time it was made, because the parties agree 
  to put the contract in writing and to make the writing part, and evidence thereof.â€Â  
  Evatt v. Campbell, 234 S.C. 1, 6, 106 S.E.2d 447, 450 (1959) (quoting 
  Mebane v. Taylor, 164 S.C. 87, 94, 162 S.E. 65, 67 (1932)). â€œNevertheless, 
  by the rules of the common law it is competent for the parties to a simple contract 
  in writing before any breach of its provisions, either altogether to waive, 
  dissolve, or abandon it, or vary or qualify its terms, and thus make a new one.â€Â  
  Id. â€œA written contract may, in the absence of statutory provisions requiring 
  a writing, be modified by a subsequent oral agreement.â€Â  Id.
In this case, Best testified 
  that Thermal entered into the written agreement with Lee for the purpose of 
  securing orders for pre-engineered products so that its manufacturing division 
  could continue production even when its engineering division was working on 
  custom-designed items.Â  Apparently, however, very few orders materialized that 
  did not require the assistance of Thermalâ€™s in-house engineering division.Â  
  Although Best stated he did not â€œknow how [Lee] got changed over to the selling 
  of other products,â€ he acknowledged that Thermal paid Lee for all orders he 
  solicited during the contract period at the same commission rate, regardless 
  of whether the items were pre-engineered.Â  Kerry Smith, Thermalâ€™s Vice President 
  and General Manager of the Control Division also acknowledged that Lee was never 
  refused a commission on the basis the order was not for a pre-engineered product.Â  
  Moreover, Smith acknowledged that he discussed this with Lee, and approved of 
  him selling engineered products.
Finally, Lee and Thermal 
  disagree as to the definition of â€œpre-engineeredâ€ and â€œengineeredâ€.Â  According 
  to Lee, Thermal never had any pre-engineered products to sell.Â  Smith acknowledged 
  it had few, if any, pre-engineered products and that most of the products Lee 
  sold wereÂ  â€œengineeredâ€ as he understood the term.Â  Counsel for Thermal maintained 
  there was an oral agreement to sell engineered products that â€œran parallelâ€ 
  to the written contract, but argued it was not incorporated into the written 
  contract;Â  therefore, the contractâ€™s notice provision was not applicable.Â  Thermalâ€™s 
  attorney conceded on Thermalâ€™s behalf that all of the jobs for which Lee was 
  compensated in the November 1995 payment, following Leeâ€™s termination, were 
  for â€œengineeredâ€ items.
While acknowledging that 
  almost from the beginning Lee secured orders mostly for custom-made products 
  that required the services of Thermalâ€™s engineering division, Thermal nevertheless 
  paid Lee throughout the contract period for all orders he secured in his territory, 
  not just for pre-engineered products.Â  Thermal also continued to pay Lee commissions, 
  per the language of their written agreement, for orders procured by others in 
  his territory, although Lee did not participate in bringing the orders to the 
  company.
We agree with the trial courtâ€™s 
  finding that the parties orally modified their written contract to encompass 
  paying Lee commissions for all products sold within Leeâ€™s exclusive territory, 
  regardless of whether the products were pre-engineered.Â  Accordingly, we affirm 
  the trial courtâ€™s ruling that Lee was due $58,465.64 in unpaid commissions that 
  accrued during the period of the contract, and subsequent to termination, as 
  per the contractâ€™s residual notice provision.
II.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Prejudgment Interest Award under 
  Rule 60(a)
Thermal next contends the 
  trial court committed reversible error in concluding Rule 60(a), SCRCP was an 
  appropriate vehicle for awarding prejudgment interest to Lee.Â  We disagree.
The judgment in this case was entered on August 
  23, 1999, but the Clerk of Court inadvertently failed to provide either party 
  with notice of entry of the judgment.Â  Leeâ€™s attorney discovered the order on 
  April 28, 2000.Â  On May 12, 2000, Lee Filed a motion under Rule 60(a), SCRCP 
  asserting the trial court mistakenly omitted an award of prejudgment interest 
  from the order, and that he was entitled to prejudgment interest on the unpaid 
  commissions as matter of law.Â  Thermal opposed the motion, arguing Rule 60(a) 
  was not a proper procedural mechanism for recovering prejudgment interest because 
  the failure to include interest was not the result of a clerical mistake.Â Â Â Â Â  

After a hearing, the trial court granted Leeâ€™s 
  motion and awarded him prejudgment interest of $16,901.61.Â  The court notedÂ  
  Lee submitted a detailed chart at trial with calculations of the prejudgment 
  interest.Â  â€œIn addition, the parties agreed that the payment date for each invoice 
  was 60 days after the invoice date, unless shown otherwise.Â  Since payment of 
  [Leeâ€™s] commission was due fifteen days after [Thermal] received its invoice 
  payments, the commissions were due seventy-five days after the invoice payment 
  date.Â  [Leeâ€™s] exhibit 16 calculated interest at the rate of 8 and 3/4%, per 
  S.C. Code Ann.Â§ 34-31-20(A).â€Â  The court found the amount of prejudgment interest 
  due was â€œeasily ascertainable from [Leeâ€™s] exhibit 16.â€Â  The court stated although 
  Leeâ€™s exhibit showed interest accruing after 60 days, the amount of interest 
  could be adjusted and â€œis easily ascertainable and calculable on the basis of 
  the record before this Court.â€
The statutory basis for the award of prejudgment interest 
  is section 34-31-20(A), which provides:

In all cases of accounts stated and in all cases wherein 
  any sum or sums of money shall be ascertained and being due, shall draw interest 
  according to law, the legal interest rate shall be at the rateÂ  of eight and 
  three-fourths percent per annum.

S.C. Code Ann Â§ 34-31-20(A) (1987) (emphasis added).
â€œPrejudgment interest is 
  allowed on liabilities to pay money from the time when, either by agreement 
  of the parties or operation of law, the payment was demandable, if the sum is 
  certain or capable of being reduced to certaintyâ€¦.The right of a party to 
  prejudgment interest is not affected by rights of discount or setoff claimed 
  by the opposing party.Â  It is the character of the claim and not of the defense 
  to it that determines whether prejudgment interest is allowable.â€Â  S. Welding 
  Works, Inc. v. K & S Constr. Co., 286 S.C. 158, 164, 332 S.E.2d 102, 
  106 (Ct. App. 1985) (citations omitted) (emphasis added).
Rule 60(a), SCRCP provides 
  â€œ[c]lerical mistakes in judgments, orders or other parts of the record and errors 
  therein arising from oversight or omission may be corrected by the court at 
  any time of its own initiative or on the motion of any party and after such 
  notice, if any, as the court orders.â€
Wright & Miller, discussing 
  the types of errors covered by the federal rule 60(a), which is virtually identical 
  to South Carolinaâ€™s rule, state in pertinent part:

The court may correct clerical errors and mathematical computations.Â  
  It has been held that it also may correctâ€¦the addition of costs to a judgment.Â  
  The judgment may be corrected by including interest if this is a matter of 
  right but not if allowing interest is discretionary.

11Charles A. Wright & Arthur Miller, Federal Practice and Procedure 
  Â§ 2854 (1973).
The commentators further 
  state:

There is a considerable overlap between Rule 59(e) and Rule 
  60.Â  It has been held that a motion for amendment of the judgment to include 
  prejudgment interest is under Rule 60(a), and is not subject to the time limit 
  of Rule 59(e), if the party is entitled to interest as a matter of right, 
  but that if allowance of prejudgment interest is in the discretion of the court 
  then the ten-day limit of Rule 59(e) applies.

Id. Â§ 2817 (emphasis added).
There apparently was no real 
  dispute at trial that the statutory provision for prejudgment interest was applicable 
  to Leeâ€™s claim.Â  The trial court noted in its order that both parties agreed 
  that the pleadings would be construed to assert a claim for pre-judgment interest.Â  
  The court found the amount of prejudgment interest was easily ascertainable 
  from the evidence presented during the trial.
Although it is proper to 
  make this motion within the time limits of Rule 59(e), there is authority that 
  where interest is available as a matter of right, rather than discretion, the 
  interest may properly be sought in a Rule 60(a) motion.Â  See, e.g., State, 
  Personnel Bd. v. Akers, 797 So. 2d 422, 426 n.4 (Ala. 2000) (holding Court 
  has authority under Rule 60(a), Ala R. Civ. P., to correct omissions of pre-judgment 
  interest from a judgment where the court intended to grant pre-judgment interest, 
  but failed to do so, or where the judgment did not include pre-judgment interest 
  mandated by law);Â  Brooks v. Jackson, 813 P.2d 847, 849 (Colo. Ct. App. 
  1991) (The failure to include interest in a judgment, when the law provides 
  for the award of pre-judgment interest, is an oversight which fits squarely 
  within the parameters of Rule 60(a);Â  therefore, the addition of interest to 
  a verdict is a ministerial act that is mandatory and does not require the exercise 
  of judgment or discretion.).Â  But see Jennings v. Ibarra, 921 
  P.2d 62, 65 (Colo. Ct App. 1996) (holding a Rule 60(a) motion could not be used 
  to include pre-judgment interest in the circumstances where it was clear the 
  trial court did not originally intend to make such an award. The court rejected 
  the position that a failure to include an award of mandatory pre-judgment interest 
  is always to be viewed as an oversight or omission which is correctable at any 
  time by amendment of the judgment under Rule 60(a).)
Because pre-judgment interest 
  is mandatory under the statute for this type of claim, we find no error in the 
  trial courtâ€™s decision to correct this omission under 60(a), especially in light 
  of the fact that the parties were not given notice of entry of the order in 
  the usual manner.1 
  Accordingly, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s award of pre-judgment interest to Lee.
III.Â Â Â  Sales Representatives Act,Â§ 39-65-10 to 
  -80
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Thermal asserts the trial 
  court erred in applying the Sales Representatives Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-65-10 
  to â€“80, to Leeâ€™s claims, because Lee did not solicit wholesale orders as required 
  by the Act.Â  Therefore, Thermal argues Lee was not entitled to punitive damages 
  or attorney fees.Â  We agree.
S.C. Code Ann. Section 39-65-20 (Supp. 2001) provides: 
  â€œWhen a contract between a sales representative and a principalÂ  
  is terminated for any reason, the principal shall pay the sales representative 
  all commissions that have or will accrue under the contract to the sales representative 
  according to the terms of the contract.â€Â  (emphasis added).
The Act defines a â€œprincipalâ€ as one who:

(a) manufactures, produces, imports, or distributes 
  a tangible product for wholesale;
(b) contracts with a sales representative to solicit orders for the 
  product;Â  and
(c) compensates the sales representative, in whole or in 
  part, by commission.

Id. Â§ 39-65-10(3) (emphasis added).
A â€œsales representativeâ€ is a person who:

  (a)
  contracts with a principal to 
  solicit wholesale orders;
  (b) is compensated, in whole or in part by commission;
  (c) does not place orders or purchase 
  for his own account or for resale;Â  and
  (d)  does not sell or take orders 
  for the sale of product to the ultimate consumer.

Id.Â§ 39-65-10(4) (emphasis added).
Where a violation of the 
  Act has occurred, the sales representative is entitled to sales commissions 
  plus punitive damages up to three times the amount of commissions due, plus 
  reasonable attorney fees and costs.Â  Id. Â§ 39-65-30.
â€œThe cardinal rule of statutory 
  construction is that we are to ascertain and effectuate the actual intent of 
  the legislature.â€Â  Burns v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co.,Â  297 S.C. 
  520, 522, 377 S.E.2d 569, 570 (1989).Â  â€œ[W]ords used therein must be given their 
  plain and ordinary meaning without resort to subtle or forced construction to 
  limit or expand its operation.â€Â  Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 
  309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1992).Â  â€œThe language must also be read 
  in a sense which harmonizes with its subject matter and accords with its general 
  purpose.â€Â  Id.Â  Where a word is not defined in a statute, our appellate 
  courts have looked to the usual dictionary meaning to supply its meaning.Â  See 
  e.g. Gulf Oil Corp. v. S.C. Tax Commâ€™n, 248 S.C. 267, 270, 149 S.E.2d 
  642, 643 (1966) (citing Websterâ€™s New International Dictionary for definition 
  of a statuteâ€™s reference to â€œpaid-in surplusâ€);Â  State v. Dickinson, 
  339 S.C. 194, 199, 528 S.E.2d 675, 677 (Ct. App. 2000) (citing Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 
  for definition of â€œobtainingâ€ in statute for obtaining property in fraudulent 
  manner);Â  State v. Estridge, 320 S.C. 288, 291, 465 S.E.2d 91, 93 (Ct. 
  App. 1995) (referencing dictionary definition in determining legislative intent).
Thermal argues that the Act 
  only relates to commissions earned on â€œwholesale orders.â€ Thermal defines â€œwholesaleâ€ 
  as the sale of goods in quantity usually for resale by a retail merchant.Â  Thermal 
  argues that the Act is not applicable to this case because the items manufactured 
  by Thermal were sold for use by the purchaser or were sold to manufacturers 
  to be included in a complete piece of operational equipment.Â  Thermal contends 
  that neither of these sales can be considered wholesale.Â  Therefore it argues 
  Lee is not a sales representative as defined by the Act and is not entitled 
  to attorney fees or punitive damages.
Lee avers that the Legislature 
  passed the Sales Representative Act intending to cover all workers who are not 
  paid their wages or commissions.Â  Lee therefore argues that interpreting the 
  Act to limit its application to a narrower class of workers would only serve 
  to thwart the Legislative intent behind the Act.Â  Lee agrees with the definition 
  for wholesale employed by the trial court.Â  In holding the Sale Representatives 
  Act to be applicable in this case, the trial court stated only that it found 
  â€œthe definitions of â€˜wholesaleâ€™ and â€˜retailâ€™ as defined in Roland Elect. 
  Co. v. Walling, 326 U.S. 657 (1946), to be persuasive.â€Â  In Roland, 
  the Supreme Court found among other definitions, that â€œwholesale salesâ€ means 
  buying goods for the purpose of reselling them, but could also refer to sales 
  of goods used for business purposes or made to commercial, professional, or 
  governmental users, rather than for personal or household consumption.Â  Id. 
  at 674-75.2Â  Lee contends 
  that Thermalâ€™s sales would be encompassed under this definition of â€œwholesaleâ€, 
  and he is thus entitled to attorney fees and punitive damages.
Our Sales Representative 
  Act defines a sales representative for purposes of the Act as someone who â€œcontracts 
  with a principal to solicit wholesale orders.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-65-10(4).Â  
  The South Carolina General Assembly did not include the definition of â€œwholesaleâ€ 
  or â€œwholesalerâ€ in this Act, and our research has revealed no South Carolina 
  case law that has defined these terms as they relate to this Act.Â  In interpreting 
  the words â€œwholesaleâ€ and â€œwholesalerâ€ we look to the plain and ordinary meaning 
  of these words.Â  â€œWholesaleâ€ is defined as â€œ[t]he sales of goods or commodities 
  [usually] for resale by a retailer, as opposed to a sale to the ultimate consumer.â€ 
  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 1591 (7th ed. 1999).Â  A â€œwholesalerâ€ is â€œ[o]ne 
  who buys large quantities of goods and resells them in smaller quantities to 
  retailers or other merchants, who in turn sell to the ultimate consumer.â€ Id. 
  See Am. Delta Techs., Inc. v. RK Elec. Info. Concepts, 647 A.2d 
  1344, 1347 (N.J. Super. Ct. App. Div. 1994) (stating where the terms â€œwholesaleâ€ 
  and â€œwholesale ordersâ€ were not defined in its sales representatives statutes, 
  â€œreference to the usual definition of those terms would apply;â€ the court noted 
  a â€œwholesalerâ€ is â€œ[o]ne who buys in comparatively large quantities, and then 
  resells, usually in smaller quantities, but never to the ultimate consumerâ€)(citing 
  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary).
We are persuaded that the 
  Legislature intended the usual dictionary meaning to apply to the term â€œwholesale,â€ 
  and in so intending, limited the application of this Act to a specific class 
  of workers.Â  We decline to extend the meaning of wholesale as advocated by Lee.Â  
  Whether or not all sales representative paid commissions should be covered under 
  this Act is a question better addressed by the Legislature.
We find support for our definition 
  of â€œwholesaleâ€ in at least one other jurisdiction that has considered this issue 
  in a case involving similar facts.Â  In Hoffman v. Van Pak Corp., 16 S.W. 
  3d 684 (Mo. Ct. App. 2000), the Missouri Court of Appeals held that an employer 
  which manufactured electrical control systems was not a principal within the 
  meaning of its statutes allowing damages to sale representatives who are not 
  timely paid.
The employer primarily custom-manufactured each 
  product after it was ordered and thus was mostly selling to end users, although 
  some sales were made at wholesale.Â  The Missouri court rejected the broader 
  definitions of â€œwholesaleâ€ found in Roland Electrical Co.3Â  The Hoffman court 
  noted:

The statute uses the word â€œwholesaleâ€ in defining both â€œprincipalâ€ and â€œsales 
  representative.â€ We presume that the legislature did not insert idle verbiage 
  or superfluous language in the statute.Â  Each word, clause, sentence, and section 
  of a statute should be given meaning.

* * *

It is clear that in its use of the word â€œwholesaleâ€ the 
  legislature intended to address a problem in the wholesale distribution system 
  and wholesale markets and did not intend to create additional remedies for all 
  salespersons who are paid by commission.Â  Whether such a remedy should be extended 
  to all commissioned salespeople is a question for the legislature, not the courts.Â  


Id. at 689-90 (citations omitted).
In order to recover attorney 
  fees and punitive damages, Lee must fit within the parameters of a â€œsales representativeâ€ 
  as defined in this Act.Â  The evidence at trial was that Lee solicited orders 
  of control panels to manufacturers, who in turn used the items to manufacture 
  equipment.Â  Thus, those placing the orders were, for the most part, the ultimate 
  consumer or end user of the products.Â  Further, Lee himself testified that the 
  use of the concepts of â€œwholesaleâ€ and â€œretailâ€ have no application to his work.Â  
  We find that Lee does not fit within the meaning of â€œsales representativeâ€ as 
  defined by the Act, and therefore, we reverse the trial courtâ€™s finding that 
  the Sales Representative Act is applicable to Leeâ€™s claims and, consequently, 
  reverse the courtâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s fees to Lee.
Leeâ€™s Appeal
Lee contends the trial court 
  abused its discretion in failing to award him punitive damages under the Sales 
  Representatives Act.Â  Because we conclude the Act was not applicable to Leeâ€™s 
  claim, we affirm the courtâ€™s denial of punitive damages.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, 
  we affirm the trial courtâ€™s award of past due commissions and pre-judgment interest.Â  
  Based on our finding that the Sales Representative Act4 does not apply to Leeâ€™s action because 
  he does not deal in wholesale sales, we affirm the courtâ€™s denial of punitive 
  damages under the Act and reverse the courtâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Accordingly, 
  the decision below is
AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART
STILLWELL and SHULER,
JJ. concur.

  1 Cf.Calhoun v. Calhoun, 339 S.C. 96, 102, 529 S.E.2d 
    14, 18 (2000) (stating in a case involving section 34-31-20(b)â€™s provision 
    for post-judgment interest, that the â€œ[u]se of the word â€˜shallâ€™ in a statutory 
    provision indicates the provision is mandatoryâ€).
 
  2 Roland was superseded by statute.Â  Hodgson v. 
    Crotty Bros. Dallas, Inc., 450 F.2d 1268, 1272 (5th Cir. 1971).

 
  Â³ â€œIn Roland Electric the question 
    before the Court was whether the exemption from the Fair Labor Standards Act 
    for employees engaged in retail or service establishments applied to the employees 
    of a firm which engaged in manufacturing and supplying electrical equipment 
    and services in interstate commerce to commercial and industrial users.Â  The 
    Court analyzed the word â€œretailâ€ by contrasting it with â€œwholesale.â€ Its conclusion, 
    that the firm in question was not a retail or service establishment under 
    the Fair Labor Standards Act, cannot be taken out of that context and fairly 
    be applied to the Missouri statue at issue here.â€ Id. at 689.

 
  4Â  Because 
    we find the Sales Representative Act is not applicable, we need not address 
    Thermalâ€™s remaining argument that the Actâ€™s provision for attorney fees is 
    unconstitutional.

THE 
  STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In 
  The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Marietta Garage, Inc.,       
        Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
South Carolina Department 
        of Public Safety,        Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Joseph J. Watson , Circuit 
  Court Judge

Opinion No. 3557Â 
Heard September 10, 2002 â€“ Filed October 28, 2002 

AFFIRMED


Robert C. Childs, III, Esq., Laura W.H. Teer, of Greenville; 
  for Appellant
Ronald K. Wray, II, Esq., Andrea Hawkins, 
  of Greenville; for Respondents.

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  Marietta 
  Garage, Inc., appeals the grant of summary judgment to the South Carolina Department 
  of Public Safety in an action for damages Marietta allegedly sustained from 
  the removal of its name from a wrecker rotation list.Â  We affirm.
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
The South Carolina Highway Patrol, pursuant to regulations 
  promulgated by the South Carolina Department of Public Safety, maintainsÂ  wrecker 
  rotation lists within established towing zones to provide towing services to 
  motorists. [1] Â  The regulations provide that, 
  unless the owner or driver of a wrecked or disabled vehicle requests a specific 
  wrecker service to tow the vehicle, the Patrol contacts a wrecker service from 
  the rotation list for the zone where towing is required. 
  [2] Â  Companies on the list are contacted in the order in which they 
  appear. [3] Â  To remain on the rotation list 
  for a particular towing zone, a wrecker service must be either physically located 
  within the zone or maintain a separate business and storage lot within the zone. 
  [4] Â  
Marietta has been on various wrecker rotation lists since the Department adopted 
  this practice.Â  On November 8, 1995, the Patrol approved Mariettaâ€™s request 
  to be placed on the list for zone 5, where Marietta had an office and access 
  to a storage facility. Â The office and storage facility were on the premises 
  of Fender Mender, a business located at 205 North Pleasantburg Drive.Â  Marietta 
  had an oral agreement with Fender Mender allowing Marietta to store vehicles 
  on Fender Menderâ€™s property in exchange for splitting the storage fees. 
On February 8, 1996, the 
  Patrol contacted Marietta to tow a vehicle belonging to Chris Busha.Â  Busha 
  had been involved in a single-car accident about one-half mile from Mariettaâ€™s 
  North Pleasantburg Drive location.
Robert Pritchett, 
  Mariettaâ€™s general manager, went to the scene to tow the vehicle to the North 
  Pleasantburg Drive location.Â  When Pritchett arrived at Fender Mender, 
  however, he noticed the Marietta Garage sign was missing and the lock had been 
  cut.Â  Pritchett then towed the vehicle to Mariettaâ€™s home office, which 
  was approximately sixteen miles from the accident scene.
Subsequently, unbeknownst 
  to Marietta, Jean Busha, Chris Bushaâ€™s mother, complained to the Patrol about 
  the towing charge for her sonâ€™s vehicle.Â  After receiving Jean Bushaâ€™s 
  complaint, Lt. Kimbrell of the Patrol drove to the North Pleasantburg Drive 
  location and learned from the proprietors of Fender Mender that Fender 
  Mender and Marietta had ceased doing business with each other.Â  On February 
  16, 1996, Marietta was removed from the rotation list for zone 5 without a hearing 
  and was notified in writing of the removal a few days later.
Marietta requested a hearing 
  to contest its removal from the rotation list.Â  The request was granted, 
  and the hearing took place June 10, 1996.Â  At the hearing, Marietta informed 
  the Patrol that it had acquired a new location in zone 5.Â  The Patrol inspected the new site and, on November 10, 
  1996, reinstated Marietta to the rotation list for zone 5.Â  
  On November 26, 1996, however, the Department informed Marietta in writing that 
  it was upholding the earlier decision to remove Marietta from the list â€œfor 
  the simple reason that the location of 205 [North] Pleasantburg Drive is no 
  longer occupied by Marietta Garage.â€
After receiving this notification 
  from the Department, Marietta filed a complaint in the circuit court against 
  the Department requesting damages allegedly resulting from gross negligence 
  on the part of the Department and from the unconstitutional taking of Mariettaâ€™s 
  property rights. [5] Â  Marietta determined it had missed about twenty rotation calls during the time 
  it was off the rotation list for zone 5 up until the administrative hearing 
  on June 10, 1996.
Both sides moved for summary 
  judgment.Â  On October 17, 1997, the circuit court issued an order denying summary 
  judgment to Marietta and granting summary judgment to the Department. 
Marietta appealed the grant 
  of summary judgment to the Department.Â  On September 17, 1999, this court, in 
  a published opinion, affirmed the grant of summary judgment on Mariettaâ€™s gross 
  negligence claim, but further held the Department violated the South Carolina 
  Administrative Procedures Act (APA) by failing to conduct a pre-removal hearing 
  before removing Marietta from the rotation list for zone 5. [6] Â  Because of the determination 
  that â€œ[t]he Departmentâ€™s failure to provide Marietta notice and a hearing prior 
  to actual removal violated the APA,â€ the case was remanded to the circuit court 
  for further proceedings. [7] 
On remand, the Department 
  again moved for summary judgment.Â  The circuit court granted the motion, holding 
  (1) Mariettaâ€™s claim for damages as a result of the Departmentâ€™s APA violation 
  was moot, and (2) Marietta could not recover damages for inverse condemnation 
  because it had failed to allege a compensable property interest.Â  Again, 
  Marietta appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
1. Marietta first argues the circuit court erred 
  in ruling that its claim for damages under the APA was moot.Â  We disagree.
 â€œA case becomes moot when judgment, if rendered, 
  will have no practical legal effect upon [the] existing controversy.Â  This is 
  true when some event occurs making it impossible for [the] reviewing Court to 
  grant effectual relief.â€ [8] 
In the present case, there is no meaningful relief 
  that either this court or the trial court could now give Marietta.Â  In this 
  courtâ€™s prior opinion, we held the Department had violated the APA by failing 
  to hold a hearing before removing Marietta from the rotation list. 
  [9] Â  Notwithstanding the finding that a violation occurred, Marietta 
  received a hearing and was eventually reinstated to the list.Â  The only question 
  remaining is whether Marietta is entitled to money damages for the APA violation 
  as compensation for the time it was not on the list.
The APA allows a party to seek judicial review 
  upon exhaustion of administrative remedies. [10] Â  It does not, however, specifically provide for 
  the assessment of civil penalties against an agency found to be in violation 
  of its provisions.Â  We have not foundâ€”nor has Marietta directed our attention 
  toâ€”any authority indicating that an aggrieved party may seek money damages under 
  the APA or under any analogous legislation absent an express provision recognizing 
  such a claim. [11] 
  2.  Marietta further contends the circuit court erred in granting summary 
  judgment to the Department on Mariettaâ€™s inverse condemnation claim, contending 
  it was â€œdeprived . . . of a protected property right without compensation.â€Â  
  We hold summary judgment was proper.
To prove an inverse condemnation, a plaintiff must show: 
  (1) an affirmative, positive, aggressive act on the part of the governmental 
  agency; (2) a taking; (3) the taking is for a public use; and (4) the taking 
  has some degree of permanence. 
  [12] Â  â€œThe threshold inquiry is whether the property interest affected 
  is inherent in the plaintiffâ€™s ownership rights or completely dependent upon 
  regulatory licensing.â€ [13] Â Â Â  
In Pritchett v. Alford, 
  [14]  the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals held that, once a wrecker 
  service is placed on a wrecker rotation list, it acquires a constitutionally 
  protected property right not to be removed from the list without Fourteenth 
  Amendment procedural due process requirements. [15] Â  Nonetheless, we hold that, 
  even when the record is viewed in the light most favorable to Marietta, the 
  inverse condemnation claim must fail because there is nothing to suggest that 
  there was a taking for a public use.Â  
Marietta argues only that the rotation list was â€œa list maintained 
  for the publicâ€™s benefit.â€Â  Like the plaintiff in Gasque v. Town of Conway, [16]  who unsuccessfully claimed damages resulting 
  from the refusal of the municipal authorities to grant him a permit to build 
  and operate a gasoline filling station within the town, Marietta cannot show, 
  either â€œdirectly or indirectly,â€  [17]  that its place on the rotation list was â€œsubjected 
  to a public useâ€ [18]  
  during the time Marietta was removed from the list. 
  [19] Â  At best, it has demonstrated only that its removal benefitted 
  other wrecker services on the rotation list.
   3.  Marietta also contends the circuit court inaccurately portrayed 
  several allegations as undisputed facts in the case.Â  The specific findings 
  with which Marietta appears to take issue concern:Â  (1) whether Department regulations 
  require that a lot be inspected before it is placed on the wrecker rotation 
  list; (2) whether the rules and regulations of the Department require notification 
  for a change of address within a zone; (3) whether Marietta at all times had 
  maintained a storage lot within zone 5; (4) whether a predeprivation hearing 
  was feasible; (5) whether circumstances necessitated quick removal of Marietta 
  by the Department from the rotation list; and (6) whether there was ample opportunity 
  for the State to provide notice and an opportunity to be heard before suspending 
  Marietta from the wrecker rotation list.Â  We agree with the Department that 
  these concerns, even if resolved in Mariettaâ€™s favor, would not affect the result 
  in this case insofar as our holdings are based on our analysis of the APA and 
  our determination that there was no evidence that the alleged taking was for 
  a public use.
AFFIRMED.
HOWARD and SHULER, JJ., concur.

title: Binkley v. Burry
description: This is a legal malpractice action arising from the defendant's alleged failure to disclose the existence of an easement.  The trial court held the lawsuit was barred by the statute of limitations.  On appeal, the plaintiffs contend (1) the trial judge made rulings that conflicted with a previous order by another trial judge in the case and (2) there were issues of material fact that would preclude the grant of summary judgment.

  STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In 
  The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Robert W. Binkley and Susan 
        B. Binkley,        Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
John Burry,
Haynsworth,

        and Fant Engineering & Surveying Co., Inc.,

Of whom
Haynsworth, Marion,

and

v.
