        District of Fountain Inn, South Carolina,       
Third Party Defendant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â H. Dean Hall , Circuit 
  Court Judge

Opinion No. 3558
Heard SeptemberÂ  10, 2002 â€“ Filed October 
  28, 2002Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Keith M. Babcock, of Columbia; Michael Stephen Chambers, of Greenville; 
  for Appellants
John E. Johnston, of Greenville; for Respondents.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, 
  J.:Â  This is a legal malpractice action.Â  The trial 
  court granted summary judgment to Haynsworth, Marion, McKay & Guerard, LLP 
  (Haynsworth), holding Robert W. Binkley and Susan B. Binkley failed to file 
  their lawsuit within the applicable limitations period.Â  The Binkleys appeal.Â  
  We affirm.
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The Binkleys purchased lakefront property in the 
  Lakeview Acres subdivision in Greenville County, South Carolina.Â  Haynsworth 
  conducted the closing on Lot 8, the subject property, on April 19, 1991.
Â On May 2, 1991, Haynsworth sent the Binkleys their 
  deed to Lot 8 along with a letter indicating the law firm had performed a title 
  examination of the property.Â  According to the letter, Haynsworth concluded 
  the Binkleys were vested with a marketable fee simple title to the premises, 
  subject to several exceptions.Â  Included in the list of exceptions was 
  an â€œ[e]asement for construction and impoundment given to Rabon Creek Watershed 
  Conservation District recorded in Deed Book 211 at Page 657, Office of the Clerk 
  of Court for Laurens County and Deed Book 1169 at Page 88 in the RMC Office 
  for Greenville County.â€Â  The Binkleys, however, assumed the mailing contained 
  only the deed to their property, and Robert Binkley placed it in his safe without 
  reading it.Â  This letter was apparently the only communication between 
  Haynsworth and the Binkleys about the easement. Â Â Â Â Â 
On August 7, 1991, the Binkleys 
  entered into a contract for the construction of their home on Lot 8.Â  The 
  contract noted the first floor of the home would be constructed two feet above 
  the 100-year floodplain level.Â  In his deposition, however, Robert Binkley 
  conceded that, before construction of the home commenced, he was aware that 
  the lower level of the building would be in the floodplain. 
  [1] 
On November 4, 1991, 
  Haynsworth closed on a mortgage given by the Binkleys to American Federal Bank 
  and secured by Lot 8.Â  A few days before the closing, a plat had been 
  prepared indicating the elevation of the dam spillway would be higher than the 
  elevation of the lower level of the Binkleysâ€™ proposed home.Â  Robert 
  Binkley admitted he saw the plat and was aware of the elevations.Â  Furthermore, 
  the Binkleys signed a release at the closing that stated they knew the basement 
  of their home was within the 100-year floodplain level.Â  The Binkleys waived 
  the option of flood insurance and proceeded with construction on their 
  home.
The Binkleys subsequently 
  purchased Lot 9 in Lakeview Acres.Â  Lot 9 lies next to Lot 8Â  and is also lakefront 
  property.Â  Haynsworth performed the closing on March 2, 1992.Â  This time, 
  however, Haynsworth did not conduct a title search on the property.
In August 1995, heavy 
  rains caused water impounded by the Rabon Creek Watershed District to back up 
  onto the Binkleysâ€™ property and flood the basement of their home.Â  After 
  the flood, Rabon Creek informed the Binkleys and other homeowners affected by 
  the rain that it claimed an easement to the top of the dam and set out flags 
  to indicate the boundary lines of the easement around the lake.Â  The 
  pin locations indicated that the easement claimed by Rabon Creek covered all 
  of Lot 8 and almost all of Lot 9.Â  It was only after the flood that the 
  Binkleys read the letter from Haynsworth advising them of the easement that 
  encumbered Lot 8. 
On June 7, 1996, the Binkleys 
  sued Rabon Creek.Â  In addition to damages, the Binkleys sought a declaratory 
  judgment regarding the extent and enforceability of the easement. (Binkley 
  I)Â  Rabon Creek counterclaimed for a declaratory judgment, asking the court 
  to construe the easement and determine its extent.
Both sides moved for summary 
  judgment on the interpretation of the easement agreement.Â  The trial 
  court, Judge Kittredge presiding, held a hearing on the motions on September 
  17, 1996.Â  On December 23, 1996, Judge Kittredge issued an order on the 
  motions holding (1) the language of the easement was ambiguous as to its extent 
  and scope, thus necessitating resort to the intention of the parties to the 
  easement; (2) the parties intended the easement to allow Rabon Creek to â€œstoreâ€ 
  water to create a lake level of 700.5 feet; and (3) during periods of heavy 
  rain, Rabon Creek could allow the â€œflowageâ€ of water up to and over the top 
  of the dam to an elevation of 725.2 feet. [2] Â  The order further noted that 
  â€œ[v]arious issues remain to be determined,â€ such as the Binkleysâ€™ contention 
  that Rabon Creek should not be allowed to enforce the easement for equitable 
  reasons.Â  Pursuant to Rule 54(b) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil 
  Procedure, final judgment was entered to the extent of the issues decided by 
  the order. [3] Â  By consent of the parties, 
  all remaining claims and defenses were dismissed with prejudice.
Â On February 27, 1997, 
  the Binkleys commenced this action against Haynsworth alleging Haynsworth committed 
  professional malpractice in â€œfailing to disclose the existence of the [e]asement 
  or its impact.â€ [4] Â  (Binkley II)Â  
  On August 7, 1997, Judge Kittredge signed a consent order consolidating 
  this lawsuit with cases brought by other homeowners who had experienced flooding 
  during the same event that damaged the Binkleys.Â  This consolidation was for 
  the limited purposes of construing the extent of the easement and considering 
  the affirmative defenses to enforcement of the easement.Â  On September 
  8, 1997, Haynsworth filed an answer, cross-complaint, and third-party complaint 
  against Rabon Creek in Binkley II, alleging among other things that Rabon 
  Creek was estopped from enforcing the easement against the Binkleys and other 
  homeowners.Â  Judge Kittredge issued an order on September 12, 1997, in 
  which he granted summary judgment as to the existence of the easement but found 
  that genuine issues of material fact existed as to its scope and extent.Â  
  After a trial on the merits on February 17 and 18, 1998, Judge Kittredge 
  issued an order on May 5, 1998, construing the easement documents and finding 
  Rabon Creek was estopped from enforcing the easement against the homeowners, 
  but could enforce it against John Burry, the party granting the easement.
In the meantime, on August 
  19, 1997, the Binkleys moved under Rule 60 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil 
  Procedure for relief from the summary judgment order in Binkley I issued 
  by Judge Kittredge on December 23, 1996.Â  Later, on June 30, 1998, the 
  Binkleys moved to amend their complaint to assert a claim for equitable relief 
  based on the doctrine of estoppel and to assert causes of action against Rabon 
  Creek based on inverse condemnation, negligence, and trespass.Â  Finding 
  his December 1996 order in Binkley I contained inconsistencies that would 
  prejudice the Binkleys, Judge Kittredge vacated the order and, on October 2, 
  1998, granted the Binkleysâ€™ motion for consolidation.
Rabon Creek appealed both 
  Judge Kittredgeâ€™s order limiting its enforcement of the easement to Burry and 
  Judge Kittredgeâ€™s order vacating his order of December 23, 1996, and consolidating 
  Binkley I and Binkley II.Â  On appeal, this court held (1) the 
  easement extended to the top of the dam; (2) the recording of the easement gave 
  constructive notice to the homeowners; and (3) Rabon Creek was not equitably 
  estopped from enforcing the easement. 
  [5]  
While Rabon Creekâ€™s appeal 
  was pending, the Binkleysâ€™ malpractice claim proceeded in the trial court.Â  
  On December 7, 1998, Haynsworth moved for summary judgment, alleging the claim 
  was barred by the statute of limitations. 
On March 8, 2000, the trial 
  court, Judge Hall presiding, held a hearing on the motion.Â  On March 
  15, 2000, Judge Hall issued an order granting summary judgment to Haynsworth 
  on the ground that the Binkleysâ€™ malpractice claim was untimely as to their 
  purchases of both Lot 8 and Lot 9.Â  On March 24, 2000, the Binkleys moved 
  for reconsideration, alteration, or amendment of the judgment pursuant to Rules 
  59(e) and 60(b) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  Judge Hall 
  denied their motion by order dated April 24, 2000.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  NOTICE
The Binkleys first argue that, â€œ[b]ecause the issue 
  of notice had been previously litigated and decided in Judge Kittredgeâ€™s Order, 
  Judge Hall erred in re-addressing this issue and deciding it in a way that is 
  in conflict with Judge Kittredgeâ€™s previous Order.â€Â  In support of their position, 
  the Binkleys contend (1) the prior pending appeal of Judge Kittredgeâ€™s order 
  divested the trial court of jurisdiction to decide this issue; (2) the findings 
  in Judge Kittredgeâ€™s prior order are the law of the case; (3) Judge Hall did 
  not have the power to review, modify, affirm, or reverse Judge Kittredgeâ€™s findings; 
  and (4) Haynsworth was judicially estopped from adopting a position that was 
  contrary to the position it took on that issue in the prior hearing before Judge 
  Kittredge.Â  We disagree with these arguments.
A.Â  Jurisdiction
At the summary judgment motion hearing before Judge 
  Hall, the Binkleys argued the motion should be stayed while the appeal of Judge 
  Kittredgeâ€™s order was pending.
As noted in this courtâ€™s prior opinion, Judge Kittredgeâ€™s 
  order held as follows:

1) the language of the easement was ambiguous, but other 
  evidence demonstrated the parties intended for the easement to extend to the 
  top of the dam; 2) the Homeowners did not have actual or constructive knowledge 
  that Rabon Creek claimed an easement to the top of the dam; and 3) Rabon Creek 
  was equitably estopped from enforcing the easement against the Homeowners. 
  [6] Â  

Once an appeal is filed, the appellate court has 
  exclusive jurisdiction over the matter. 
  [7] Â  The tribunal from which the appeal is taken, however, may proceed 
  with matters unaffected by the appeal. 
  [8] 
Â In contrast to the issues before Judge Kittredge, 
  the issue before Judge Hall was whether Haynsworthâ€™s disclosure to the Binkleys 
  of the presence of the easement put the Binkleys on inquiry notice that â€œsome 
  claim against another party might exist.â€ 
  [9] Â  Because the accrual date for determining when the statute of 
  limitations had begun to run did not depend on findings concerning the extent 
  and enforceability of the easement, we hold Judge Hall was correct in proceeding 
  with the summary judgment motion.
  B.   Law of the Case 

The Binkleys further argue that, because Haynsworth 
  had chosen not to appeal Judge Kittredgeâ€™s order, Haynsworth must accept the 
  rulings in that order as the law of the case. [10] Â  As with the 
  Binkleysâ€™ argument concerning jurisdiction, we hold the question of notice regarding 
  the existence of an easement is distinct from the question of notice as it relates 
  to the scope and enforceability of the easement.Â  We therefore hold that, although 
  the law of the case doctrine may preclude Haynsworth from challenging Judge 
  Kittredgeâ€™s finding that the Binkleys did not have notice of the scope and enforceability 
  of the easement, the doctrine does not prevent Haynsworth from raising the issue 
  of when the Binkleys had notice of the existence of the easement.
C.Â  Judge Hallâ€™s Authority to Review Judge Kittredgeâ€™s Order
The Binkleys argue that Judge Hall effectively reversed 
  Judge Kittredgeâ€™s prior order.Â  We disagree.
Generally, one circuit court judge may not reverse 
  or modify the order of another circuit court judge. 
  [11] Â  In the present case, the issues before Judge Kittredge and 
  Judge Hall were easily distinguishable.Â  Judge Kittredge determined that Rabon 
  Creekâ€™s easement was ambiguous, that the homeowners had no actual or constructive 
  notice of it, and that the doctrine of equitable estoppel limited Rabon Creekâ€™s 
  enforcement rights.Â  Judge Hall addressed the question of when the Binkleys 
  knew or should have known that they had a potential claim for legal malpractice 
  against Haynsworth and determined that they had at least inquiry notice of their 
  claim when Haynsworth advised them that the easement existed. [12] Â  
D.Â  Judicial Estoppel
The Binkleys argue that Haynsworth, as a party to 
  and a participant in the litigation before Judge Kittredge â€œtook the position 
  that [a]ppellants and the other homeowners did not have notice that the flood 
  easement burdened their propertyâ€ and â€œshould therefore be judicially estopped 
  from adopting a conflicting position on the issue of notice for purposes of 
  its summary judgment motion.â€Â  In our view, however, the doctrine of 
  judicial estoppel is inapplicable here.
â€œJudicial estoppel precludes a party from adopting 
  a position in conflict with one earlier taken in the same or related litigation.â€ 
  [13] Â  â€œThe purpose or function of the doctrine is to protect the 
  integrity of the judicial process or the integrity of courts rather than to 
  protect litigants from allegedly improper or deceitful conduct by their adversaries.â€ [14] Â  Generally, the doctrine applies 
  to only inconsistent statements of fact and not to conclusions of law or assertions 
  of different legal theories. [15]   
At the hearing before Judge Kittredge, Haynsworth 
  took the position that the easement could not be enforced against the Binkleys 
  and other homeowners because the easement documents were vague and ambiguous 
  and because Rabon Creek failed to notify the homeowners that it claimed an easement 
  to the top of the dam.Â  When the case came before Judge Hall on Haynsworthâ€™s 
  summary judgment motion, the question was not the interpretation of the easement 
  but when the Binkleys had knowledge sufficient to put a reasonable person in 
  their situation on notice of the existence of a possible claim against Haynsworth.
II.Â  SUMMARY 
  JUDGMENT
The Binkleys argue there was a question of fact as 
  to when they were put on notice that they had a claim against Haynsworth and 
  summary judgment was therefore inappropriate.Â  We disagree.
A. Lot 8
The Binkleys do not dispute the premise that the applicable 
  limitations period for their claim against Haynsworth is three years. [16] Â  Moreover, they 
  do not take issue with the principle that â€œactions must be commenced within 
  three years after the person knew or by the exercise of reasonable diligence 
  should have known that he had a cause of action.â€ [17] 
Reviewing the evidence in the light most favorable 
  to the Binkleys, we hold Judge Hall correctly determined that, as a matter of 
  law, they knew or by the exercise of reasonable diligence should have known 
  that they had a cause of action no later than November 4, 1991.Â  Robert Binkley 
  admitted he received Haynsworthâ€™s letter dated May 2, 1991, advising him and 
  his wife about the existence of the easement in question.Â  Moreover, the Binkleys 
  knew their property was located near the spillway.Â  Indeed, Robert Binkley took 
  specific steps to ensure that the main living floor of the house would be above 
  the floodplain level.Â  
In addition, at the loan closing on November 4, 1991, 
  the Binkleys signed a release indicating they had actual knowledge that their 
  property was in a floodplain, but elected not to purchase flood insurance.Â  
  
Without question, then, as early as May 1991, the 
  Binkleys had inquiry notice of a possible claim against Haynsworth regarding 
  the easement.Â  By November 4, 1991, they had actual notice of the risk of flooding 
  to their property. [18] Â  The Binkleys 
  had, then, the responsibility to investigate their claim once they had information 
  that would place a reasonable person on notice that they had a possible cause 
  of action.Â  
Finally, we reject the Binkleysâ€™ argument that knowledge 
  of the existence of the easement was insufficient to provide them with notice 
  that they may have sustained damages.Â  An easement by its very nature involves 
  the right to encroach upon anotherâ€™s property. 
  [19] Â  Moreover, once a reasonable person has reason to believe â€œthat 
  some right of his has been invaded or that some claim against another party 
  might exist,â€ [20]  the requirement 
  of reasonable diligence to investigate this information further takes precedence 
  over the inability to ascertain the amount of damages or even the possibility 
  that damages may be forthcoming at all. 
  [21] 
B. Lot 9
The Binkleys state in their brief that all the arguments 
  advanced regarding Lot 8 apply equally to Lot 9.Â  Because we have upheld Judge 
  Hallâ€™s determination that the Binkleysâ€™ malpractice action regarding Lot 8 was 
  barred by the statute of limitations, we likewise hold their action concerning 
  Lot 9 was untimely as well.
AFFIRMED.
HOWARD and SHULER, JJ., concur.

    probably the spillway.â€ 

 
   
    [2] Â Â  The order, however, further 
    noted that â€œthe spillway (assuming proper operation) will almost certainly 
    preclude â€˜flowageâ€™ beyond 718 feet.â€

 
   
     
    [3] Â Â  See Rule 54(b), SCRCP (stating

    [4]  In addition to Haynsworth, the Binkleys also named

    to the ruling of the court below, that ruling, right or wrong, was the law 
    of the case).

 
   
    [11] Â Â  Enoree Baptist Church v. Fletcher,

A:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Linda and Chris Green York.
Q:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  They ever work in the school district?
A:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Never heard of them.Â  Jim and 
  Cindy Monise.
Q:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Ever worked in the school district?
A:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  No, never heard of them.Â  Christopher 
  Mueller, Mark Harris, George and Pat Krane.
Q:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Ever worked in the school district?
A:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  No.
Follin presented two expert 
  witnesses who stated that it was not unusual for an agency to issue a voided 
  invoice, called an â€œinformation onlyâ€ invoice, to a client who wanted to consider 
  taking a trip and needed the pricing information.Â  The two experts testified 
  it was normal for an agency to have only one agent handling corporate accounts 
  and it was not unusual for an agent to hand-deliver tickets. 
Follin explained the process 
  of booking travel at trial.Â  Once a travel agency obtains information from a 
  client regarding a trip, the agency issues an invoice and an airline ticket.Â  
  At the end of the week, the agency must make a report to the Airline Reporting 
  Corporation (â€œARCâ€), and within ten days, the ARC drafts the cost of the trip 
  from the agencyâ€™s checking account. If the client cancels the trip by the Friday 
  of that same week, the ticket and invoice are voided, ARC never drafts the cost 
  of the ticket from the agency, and the record does not appear in the accounting 
  system.Â  If the client cancels after Friday, the ARC will still draft the cost 
  of the trip from the agency and the agency must later obtain a refund.Â  Follin 
  declared that, before 1996, travel agents made a commission of 10% on airline 
  tickets, but the commission was capped at $50 for a roundtrip ticket and $25 
  for a one-way ticket after 1997.
Follin professed that she 
  was almost always the travel agent from Follin Travel who handled District 17 
  travel arrangements with Klein.Â  She set up four accounts related to District 
  17 travel and Klein: (1) Account number 2099 for District 17â€™s â€œLeisure/Incentive 
  Travelâ€; (2) Account number 2022 for general District 17 travel; (3) Account 
  number 214 for District 17 school group travel; and (4) Account number 209 for 
  Kleinâ€™s personal travel.Â  Follin admitted that all four accounts were 
  funded by payments from District 17. District 17 accounted for between 8% and 
  15% of Follin Travelâ€™s total business from 1989 to 1997. 
Follin believed the Leisure/Incentive 
  travel account covered leisure trips organized by District 17 as incentives.Â  
  Klein told her the District 17 employees would reimburse the district for the 
  cost of the trip through payroll deductions.Â  Follin stated she believed that 
  the individuals traveling on all of the leisure trips paid for by District 17, 
  including the skiing trip to Colorado and both cruises, were reimbursing the 
  district.Â  Follin went on the skiing trip and the â€œcruise to nowhereâ€ as an 
  escort, but her expenses were complimentary to her as a travel agent and nothing 
  was billed to District 17, other than the costs of things not complimentary.
Follin denied knowing anything 
  about Kleinâ€™s scheme to defraud District 17.Â  Although Klein instructed her 
  to deal exclusively with him, it was not unusual to have one contact on a corporate 
  account.Â  Follin said that Klein periodically would request an invoice for a 
  school groupâ€™s travel and would request her to void it the same week.Â  Because 
  the travel was voided and no longer appeared in her accounting system and the 
  checks would be issued days to weeks later and may include payment for several 
  voided invoices, it was not possible for her to recognize or recall that an 
  amount included in the check from District 17 matched the amount on a particular 
  voided invoice.Â  Further, as the checks did not list the invoice number on them, 
  Follin received instructions from Klein as to which invoice number to apply 
  the funds.Â  Because the checks were signed by Klein and the superintendent, 
  Follin testified that she did not suspect anything was out of the ordinary with 
  the checks.Â  Follin denied on cross-examination ever getting a check from District 
  17 the day after drafting a voided invoice.Â  However, when shown copies of voided 
  invoices with checks issued in that amount by District 17 the next day, Follin 
  stated she could not recall those incidents.
Â Follin stated she first 
  suspected Klein might have been involved in wrong-doing in September 1997 when 
  she requested a deposit for a cruise he had booked and he immediately asked 
  her for a voided invoice in the same amount for a school group.Â  Follin testified 
  that she created the invoice, but no longer handled travel arrangements with 
  Klein after that time.
Follin described the events 
  leading to the creation of the â€œcredit.â€Â  According to Follin, Klein called 
  her on a Sunday sometime in early October and requested that she meet him at 
  her office.Â  Klein asked her to create false statements, back-dated to June 
  30, 1997, which indicated that District 17 had a large credit due to purchased 
  trips that were canceled.Â  Reviewing Follinâ€™s copies of District 17â€™s voided 
  invoices, Klein deduced which of the 1997 trips would be audited and he told 
  Follin she would be asked about them.Â  Klein instructed Follin to tell District 
  17 officials that he directed her to maintain the credit instead of issuing 
  a refund check.Â  Follin declared that Klein commented about her grandson, whom 
  she had custody of, during the meeting.Â  Because he had never done that before, 
  Follin said she felt Klein was threatening her life and her grandsonâ€™s life 
  if she did not create the false credit statements as he asked.Â  However, Follin 
  refused to shred the documents concerning District 17 travel as Klein requested.Â  
  Follin kept the cashierâ€™s checks Klein and Adams brought later that week in 
  her safe deposit box at her bank.
Follin testified regarding 
  her conversations with Principal Raffield and District 17 Attorney Davis during 
  their investigation of District 17 travel.Â  Follin admitted telling them that 
  District 17 had a credit and showing them the false statements.Â  She stated 
  that, when asked for the refund, she told them the money was at an out-of-town 
  bank.Â  Follin later wrote a check for $70,389.10 to District 17.Â  Although Follin 
  initially pretended District 17 was owed a â€œrefund,â€ she eventually admitted 
  to SLED that Klein had given her the money and turned over all her documents.Â  
  However, Follin denied conspiring with Klein to defraud District 17 and denied 
  receiving anything from the transactions other than her normal commission.
Criminal conspiracy is â€œa 
  combination between two or more persons for the purpose of accomplishing an 
  unlawful object or lawful object by unlawful means.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-17-410 
  (Supp. 2001).Â  To constitute conspiracy, there must be an agreement or a mutual 
  understanding.Â  State v. Horne, 324 S.C. 372, 478 S.E.2d 289 (Ct. App. 
  1996).Â  Proof of an express agreement or direct evidence of the agreement is 
  not essential, but the conspiracy may be shown by circumstantial evidence and 
  the actions of the parties.Â  State v. Kelsey, 331 S.C. 50, 502 S.E.2d 
  63 (1998).Â  â€œThe substantive crimes committed in furtherance of the conspiracy 
  constitute circumstantial evidence of the existence of the conspiracy, its object, 
  and scope.â€Â  State v. Gosnell, 341 S.C. 627, 636, 535 S.E.2d 453, 458 
  (Ct. App. 2000).
Viewing the evidence in 
  the light most favorable to the State, Klein would not have been able to proceed 
  with his travel scheme without Follinâ€™s assistance.Â  Despite the fact that there 
  was not a spoken agreement between the two to defraud District 17, the uncontradicted 
  evidence showed that Follin knowingly assisted Klein by creating false records 
  indicating District 17 had a credit.Â  Klein testified that he and Follin conspired 
  through their actions.Â  Although the agreement was not written or verbalized, 
  evidence was presented that an arrangement was reached between Klein and Follin 
  to defraud District 17.Â  Because there was evidence that reasonably tended to 
  prove Follin conspired with Klein, the trial judge properly denied Follinâ€™s 
  motion for a directed verdict as to this charge.Â  
B.Â  Aiding and Abetting
Follin contends the trial 
  court should have granted her motion for a directed verdict as to the charge 
  of aiding and abetting embezzlement because there was no evidence that she had 
  the intent to defraud District 17.Â  She asserts the evidence shows at most that 
  she was an accessory after the fact.Â  We disagree.Â  
Follin was indicted for 
  aiding and abetting embezzlement in violation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-13-210 
  (Supp. 2001).Â  Section 16-13-210 provides that it is â€œunlawful for an officer 
  or other person charged with the safekeeping, transfer, and disbursement of 
  public funds to embezzle these funds.â€Â Â  
At the close of the Stateâ€™s 
  case, Follin moved for a directed verdict on the embezzlement charge.Â  The trial 
  judge denied her motion.Â  At the close of all the evidence, Follin renewed her 
  motion.Â  The trial court found that Follinâ€™s act of knowingly creating false 
  invoices at Kleinâ€™s request to help him avoid detection was evidence of aiding 
  and abetting the embezzlement. Â The trial court denied Follinâ€™s directed verdict 
  motion.
When the factual presentation 
  is viewed in the light most favorable to the State, the evidence was sufficient 
  to go to the jury.Â  Follin knowingly assisted Klein in hiding his fraud.Â  Klein 
  testified Follin implicitly agreed to assist him by submitting false invoices 
  and then crediting the amounts paid on the invoices to his personal travel.Â  
  Because there was sufficient evidence to submit the matter to the jury, the 
  trial court did not err in denying Follinâ€™s directed verdict motion.
C.Â  Obtaining Goods and Services by False Pretenses
Follin argues the trial 
  court erred by denying her motion for a directed verdict on the charge of obtaining 
  goods and services by false pretenses.Â  We disagree.
After the State presented 
  its case, Follin moved for a directed verdict on the charge of obtaining property 
  by false pretenses, which was denied by the trial court.Â  At the close of all 
  the evidence, Follin renewed her motion, which was denied. 
Section 16-13-240 provides 
  that it is a felony for a person to, â€œby false pretense or representation[,] 
  obtain[] the signature of a person to a written instrument or obtain[] from 
  another person any chattel, money, valuable security, or other property, real 
  or personal, with intent to cheat and defraud a person of that property.â€Â  S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 16-13-240 (Supp. 2001).Â  
Although Follin claims 
  no evidence was presented which showed she made any false representations to 
  District 17 in order to obtain money, the evidence, when viewed in a light most 
  favorable to the State, lends a different conclusion.Â  Follin provided voided 
  invoices to Klein and accepted payment for them from District 17.Â  This was 
  evidence of a false representation.Â  Accordingly, we find there was sufficient 
  evidence to deny the motion for a directed verdict and to submit the matter 
  to the jury.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, 
  Follinâ€™s convictions and sentences are
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, J., concurs 
  in a separate opinion.
CONNOR, J., dissents 
  in a separate opinion.
STILWELL, J.:Â  (Concurring)
I concur in Judge Andersonâ€™s opinion, but write separately 
  to focus on what I consider to be an extremely difficult task faced by an appellate 
  court in passing upon the acceptability of the sentence imposed in this case.
It is an undeniable fact 
  that for generations trial courts have not only been allowed but actually encouraged 
  to consider the entry of a guilty plea as an ameliorating factor in structuring 
  an appropriate sentence.Â  In stark contrast, it is now and has been for many 
  years totally unacceptable to impose a harsher sentence because a defendant 
  demands a jury trial rather than entering a guilty plea.Â  These two concepts 
  are almost irreconcilable.

Here, the sentencing judge made statements 
  that clearly indicated his motivation for imposing a somewhat harsher sentence 
  upon this defendant than upon other defendants who entered guilty pleas was 
  based upon acceptable considerations.Â  At the same time, the sentencing judge 
  made remarks that can be and have been interpreted as being violative of recent 
  decisions of this court and the supreme court.Â 
The question, then, is which of the two diametrically 
  opposite statements are we to consider as controlling in judging his motivation?Â  
  Are we to look exclusively at those statements that are unacceptable, disregarding 
  the acceptable, or do we do just the opposite and disregard the unacceptable 
  in favor of the acceptable?

Under the circumstances of this case, perhaps the 
  best thing if not the only thing to do is to disregard the statements altogether 
  or consider them neutral on the issue of his motivation, and determine whether, 
  on the record, the sentence imposed is justified in comparison to the more lenient 
  sentence imposed on other defendants.Â  Using that as the criteria, this sentence 
  is unquestionably justified.
CONNOR, J. (dissenting):Â  
  I respectfully dissent from Issue II in the majority opinion and would reverse 
  Follinâ€™s sentence and remand for resentencing.Â  The trial judge committed an 
  error of law by improperly considering Follinâ€™s decision to proceed with a jury 
  trial.Â  As noted by the majority, the trial judge made it quite clear by his 
  statements that he was giving Follin a harsher sentence because she had not 
  pled guilty, as most of her co-defendants had.
He specifically 
  stated he gave consideration to the defendants who entered guilty pleas and 
  admitted their guilt. [6] [1]Â  The judge further asserted he could not 
  ignore another defendantâ€™s admission of guilt. [7] [2]Â  Such sentencing comments have been expressly 
  disapproved and warrant reversal.Â  See Davis v. State, 336 S.C. 
  329, 520 S.E.2d 801 (1999) (disapproving the trial judgeâ€™s statements regarding 
  other defendantsâ€™ guilty pleas and admissions of guilt); State v. Brouwer, 
  346 S.C. 375, 387, 550 S.E.2d 915, 922 (Ct. App. 2001) (disapproving the trial 
  judgeâ€™s â€œserious consideration for someone admitting their guiltâ€ as being â€œthe 
  first step towards rehabilitationâ€).
Furthermore, I disagree 
  with the majorityâ€™s interpretation of Brouwer.Â  Specifically, the majorityâ€™s 
  conclusion that â€œwhen the record clearly reflects an appropriate basis for a 
  disparate sentence, the sentencing judge may impose a different sentence on 
  a co-defendant in a criminal trialâ€ is troubling.Â  In my opinion, a sentencing 
  review pursuant to Brouwer requires us to confine our analysis to the 
  judgeâ€™s comments on the record at sentencing.Â  I do not believe the language 
  of Brouwer permits a de novo review of whether there is an â€œappropriate 
  basisâ€ for a sentence, especially where, as here, to do so would negate a judgeâ€™s 
  comments which are clearly based on an improper consideration of a defendantâ€™s 
  decision to exercise her right to a jury trial. 

 
   
    [1] Â  Follin erroneously refers to this entity as the â€œStatewide 
    Grand Jury.â€Â  As clearly indicated in the statute, this judicial body is known 
    as the State Grand Jury.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-7-1600 (Supp. 2001).

 
   
    [2] Â  The same judge presided over Martinâ€™s 
    jury trial and sentenced him to three concurrent terms of ten years, suspended 
    upon the service of one year and five years probation.Â  At the hearing on 
    Martinâ€™s motion for reconsideration, the trial judge noted that he was not 
    punishing Martin for exercising his right to a jury trial, but he gave consideration 
    to the others who pled guilty:
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  No 
    one should be punished because they have exercised their right to have a trial 
    by jury.
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
  
  It occurred to me in sentencing not 
    as a punishment, but what do you use as a minimum sentence?Â  How is that â€“ 
    how can that be for the person who admits their guilt versus a person for 
    trial?Â  If everybody is to be treated the same, then we â€“ there would never 
    be any distinction.Â  And none of the case law that we have had or none of 
    the things that we have all said throughout the practice of law would have 
    no meaning at all. 
  
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
  
  He didnâ€™t stand up and admit as the 
    other persons did admit that I did something wrong and not only did I admit 
    that Iâ€™m doing something wrong, but I admit and Iâ€™m willing to pay â€œXâ€ number 
    of dollars.Â  Those are factors . . . .
  
  If those arenâ€™t factors that a court 
    should consider then the Supreme Court needs to come out and say so and I 
    would urge them to do so . . . .
  Restitution is a part of it.Â  Itâ€™s 
    a part that I will consider. 
  . . . .
  . . . I have to fashion a sentence 
    given that set of circumstances, then I have to fashion a sentence for somebody 
    that comes up and says Iâ€™m guilty, I admit my guilt, Iâ€™m wrong, and not only 
    am I guilty but, Your Honor, I â€“ I cost the State or I cost the victim in 
    this situation â€œXâ€ number of dollars and I want to repay that.Â  
  That is the distinction, not what 
    he is saying to me, but that is the distinction that I have to determine.Â  
    Is that person entitled to some consideration?
  . . . .
    . . . The other people got consideration 
    for their sentence because they entered a guilty plea.
  . . . .
    . . . I gave credit for admitting 
    guilt.

 
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
     [3] Â  The trial judge in the present case was the trial 
    judge in Brouwer.Â  

 
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
     [4] Â  The co-defendant was sentenced to two years imprisonment 
    plus a $5,000 fine, with the sentence suspended upon payment of $750 and two 
    years probation.

 
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
     [5] Â  The sentence for conspiracy is no more than five 
    years.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-17-410 (Supp. 2001).Â  The sentence for embezzlement 
    of public funds is no greater than ten years where the amount of funds embezzled 
    is $5,000 or more.Â  If the amount is less than $5,000, the sentence shall 
    be no more than five years.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-13-210 (1)-(2) (Supp. 2001).Â  
    Finally, the sentence for obtaining a signature or property by false pretenses 
    is no more than ten years where the property is valued at $5,000 or more.Â  
    S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-13-240(1) (Supp. 2001).Â  

 
   
    [6] [1]Â  For example, in Johnny Martinâ€™s case, the 
    trial judge stated â€œ[t]he other people got consideration for their sentence 
    because they entered a guilty plea. . . .Â  I gave credit for admitting guilt.â€ 
    The trial judge specifically incorporated these statements during Follinâ€™s

    [7] [2]Â Â  The trial judge stated, â€œas I mentioned 
    in sentencing Johnny Martin and I have said throughout and will continue to

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court 
  of Appeals


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Brent P. Guthrie,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Oconee County
C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Circuit 
  Court Judge

Opinion No. 3560
Heard September 11, 2002 
  â€“ Filed October 28, 2002

REVERSED

Deputy Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of South 
  Carolina Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Charles 
  M. Condon, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy 
  Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold 
  M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor Druanne D. White, of Anderson, 
  for Respondent.

ANDERSON, J.: 
Brent P. Guthrie was convicted of first degree burglary.Â  On 
  appeal, he contends the trial court lacked subject matter jurisdiction because 
  the State improperly amended his indictment at trial.Â  We reverse.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Guthrie, Mark Velt, and Jerry Lambert broke into 
  Ed Tanneryâ€™s fishing cabin during the evening sometime between January 13 and 
  January 15, 1999.Â  The three men removed beer, a tackle box, fishing rods, and 
  several other items from the cabin.Â  They filled their truck with these items, 
  deposited them in Veltâ€™s hotel room, and returned to the cabin a second time 
  to extricate more items.Â  All three men were charged with the crime.
Guthrie was indicted for first degree burglary 
  based on the aggravating factor of unlawfully entering the dwelling during the 
  nighttime hours.Â  At the beginning of Guthrieâ€™s trial, the State moved to amend 
  the indictment to include as an additional aggravating factor Guthrieâ€™s conviction 
  of two or more prior burglaries.Â  Guthrie objected to the amendment and argued 
  the presentation of his six prior burglaries would be prejudicial to his defense.Â  
  The Circuit Court found Guthrie would not suffer any prejudice and allowed the 
  amendment.Â  Although the Circuit Court granted the amendment, it does not appear 
  from the record that the actual indictment was altered to include the additional 
  aggravating factor.
The State later submitted evidence of Guthrieâ€™s 
  six prior burglary convictions.Â  The Circuit Court instructed the jury that 
  they were not to consider the prior convictions as proof of guilt in the present 
  case, but that it was evidence that would satisfy an element of first degree 
  burglary.
Velt testified at trial regarding Guthrieâ€™s participation 
  in the burglary.Â  The jury found Guthrie guilty of first degree burglary.Â  The 
  foreman signed the verdict form on the back of the original indictment, which 
  charged the element of entering in the nighttime.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Guthrie maintains the Circuit 
  Court lacked subject matter jurisdiction because the amendment to the indictment 
  added an additional element of aggravation that was not presented to the grand 
  jury.Â  We agree.
I.Â  Subject Matter Jurisdiction
The jurisdiction of a court 
  over the subject matter of a proceeding is fundamental.Â  Brown v. State, 
  343 S.C. 342, 540 S.E.2d 846 (2001).Â  The Circuit Court does not have subject 
  matter jurisdiction to convict a defendant of an offense unless: (1) there has 
  been an indictment which sufficiently states the offense; (2) the defendant 
  has waived presentment of the indictment; or (3) the offense is a lesser included 
  offense of the crime charged in the indictment.Â  State v. Primus, 349 
  S.C. 576, 564 S.E.2d 103 (2002); State v. Timmons, 349 S.C. 389, 563 
  S.E.2d 657 (2002); State v. Lynch, 344 S.C. 635, 545 S.E.2d 511 (2001).
The lack of subject matter 
  jurisdiction can be raised at any time, can be raised for the first time on 
  appeal, and can be raised sua sponte by the court.Â  State v. 
  Brown, Op. No. 3549 (S.C. Ct. App. Filed Sept. 9, 2002)(Shearouse Adv. Sh. 
  No. 32 at 52); see also State v. Ervin, 333 S.C. 351, 510 S.E.2d 
  220 (Ct. App. 1998) (holding issues related to subject matter jurisdiction may 
  be raised at any time).Â  Furthermore, lack of subject matter jurisdiction may 
  not be waived, even by consent of the parties, and should be taken notice of 
  by this Court.Â  Brown, 343 S.C. at 346, 540 S.E.2d at 848.Â  The acts 
  of a court with respect to a matter as to which it has no jurisdiction are void.Â  
  Id. at 346, 540 S.E.2d at 849; State v. Funderburk, 259 S.C. 256, 
  191 S.E.2d 520 (1972).
II.Â  Sufficiency of the Indictment
In South Carolina, an indictment 
  â€œshall be deemed and judged sufficient and good in law which, in addition to 
  allegations as to time and place, as required by law, charges the crime substantially 
  in the language of the common law or of the statute prohibiting the crime or 
  so plainly that the nature of the offense charged may be easily understood and, 
  if the offense be a statutory offense, that the offense be alleged to be contrary 
  to the statute in such case made and provided.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-20 (1985).Â  
  Thus, an indictment passes legal muster if it charges the crime substantially 
  in the language of the statute prohibiting the crime or so plainly that the 
  nature of the offense charged may be easily understood.Â  State v. Reddick, 
  348 S.C. 631, 560 S.E.2d 441 (Ct. App. 2002). 
The indictment must state the offense with sufficient 
  certainty and particularity to enable the court to know what judgment to pronounce, 
  and the defendant to know what he is called upon to answer, and whether he may 
  plead an acquittal or conviction thereon.Â  Browning v. State, 320 S.C. 
  366, 465 S.E.2d 358 (1995); State v. Hamilton, 344 S.C. 344, 543 S.E.2d 
  586 (Ct. App. 2001); State v. Ervin, 333 S.C. 351, 510 S.E.2d 220 (Ct. 
  App. 1998).Â  The true test of the sufficiency of an indictment is not whether 
  it could be made more definite and certain, but whether it contains the necessary 
  elements of the offense intended to be charged and sufficiently apprises the 
  defendant of what he must be prepared to meet.Â  Browning, 320 S.C. at 
  368, 465 S.E.2d at 359; Reddick, 348 S.C. at 635, 560 S.E.2d at 443.Â  
  An indictment phrased substantially in the language of the statute which creates 
  and defines the offense is ordinarily sufficient.Â  State v. Shoemaker, 
  276 S.C. 86, 275 S.E.2d 878 (1981).
An indictment is sufficient 
  to convey jurisdiction if it apprises the defendant of the elements of the offense 
  intended to be charged and informs the defendant of the circumstances he must 
  be prepared to defend.Â  Locke v. State, 341 S.C. 54, 533 S.E.2d 324 (2000); 
  Carter v. State, 329 S.C. 355, 495 S.E.2d 773 (1998); Hamilton, 
  344 S.C. at 364, 543 S.E.2d at 597.Â  Generally, an indictment is required to 
  perform two functions: (1) it should inform the accused of the charge against 
  him by listing the elements of the offense charged; and (2) it should be sufficiently 
  specific to protect the accused against double jeopardy.Â  State v. Bullard, 
  348 S.C. 611, 560 S.E.2d 436 (Ct. App. 2002).
South Carolina courts have 
  held that the sufficiency of an indictment must be viewed with a practical eye.Â  
  State v. Adams, 277 S.C. 115, 283 S.E.2d 582 (1981), overruled on 
  other grounds by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991).Â  
  All the surrounding circumstances must be weighed before an accurate determination 
  of whether a defendant was or was not prejudiced can be reached.Â  Id.
III.Â  Amendment of Indictment
South Carolina Code Ann. 
  section 17-19-100 (1985), states in pertinent part:

If (a) there be any defect in form in any indictments 
  or (b) on the trial of any case there shall appear to be any variance between 
  the allegations of the indictment and the evidence offered in proof thereof, 
  the court before which the trial shall be had may amend the indictment (according 
  to the proof, if the amendment be because of a variance) if such amendment does 
  not change the nature of the offense charged.

An indictment may be amended 
  provided such amendment does not change the nature of the offense charged.Â  
  State v. Lynch, 344 S.C. 635, 545 S.E.2d 511 (2001); see also 
  Granger v. State, 333 S.C. 2, 507 S.E.2d 322 (1998) (finding that, under 
  Â§ 17-19-100, an indictment may be amended at trial only if amendment does not 
  change nature of offense charged).Â  For example, an amendment which changes 
  an offense to one with increased punishment deprives the Circuit Court of subject 
  matter jurisdiction.Â  Lynch, 344 S.C. at 639, 545 S.E.2d at 513; Hopkins 
  v. State, 317 S.C. 7, 451 S.E.2d 389 (1994); State v. Riddle, 301 
  S.C. 211, 391 S.E.2d 253 (1990).Â  However, an amendment may deprive the Circuit 
  Court of jurisdiction even if it does not change the penalty.Â  See Lynch, 
  344 S.C. at 639, 545 S.E.2d at 514; Weinhauer v. State, 334 S.C. 327, 
  513 S.E.2d 840 (1999).
Amendments to an indictment 
  are permissible if: 1) they do not change the nature of the offense; 2) the 
  charge is a lesser included offense of the crime charged on the indictment; 
  or 3) the defendant waives presentment to the grand jury and pleads guilty.Â  
  State v. Myers, 313 S.C. 391, 438 S.E.2d 236 (1993).
IV.Â  Efficacy of Amendment
Guthrie asserts the trial 
  court erred in allowing the State to amend his indictment at trial by adding 
  the additional aggravating factor and, therefore, the court lacked subject matter 
  jurisdiction over his case.Â  We agree.
South Carolina Code Ann. 
  section 16-11-311(A) (Supp. 2001) provides:
(A) A person is guilty of burglary in the first 
  degree if the person enters a dwelling without consent and with intent to commit 
  a crime in the dwelling, and either:

(1) when, in effecting entry or while in the 
  dwelling or in immediate flight, he or another participant in the crime:
  
(a) is armed with a deadly weapon or explosive; 
  or
(b) causes physical injury to a person who 
  is not a participant in the crime; or
(c) uses or threatens the use of a dangerous 
  instrument; or
(d) displays what is or appears to be a knife, 
  pistol, revolver, rifle, shotgun, machine gun, or other firearm;Â  or
  
(2) the burglary is committed by a person with 
  a prior record of two or more convictions for burglary or housebreaking or a 
  combination of both; or
(3) the entering or remaining occurs in the 
  nighttime.

The relevant aggravating factors in the present 
  case involve: â€œ(2) the burglary is committed by a person with a prior record 
  of two or more convictions for burglary or housebreaking or a combination of 
  both; or (3) the entering or remaining occurs in the nighttime.â€Â  Id.
The case of State v. 
  Lynch, 344 S.C. 635, 545 S.E.2d 511 (2001), is particularly instructive.Â  
  In Lynch, the defendant was indicted for first degree burglary, with 
  the aggravating factor being that the burglary occurred in the nighttime.Â  At 
  the outset of trial, the State moved to amend the indictment to strike out the 
  words â€œin the hours during darknessâ€ and to replace that phrase with â€œcaused 
  physical injury.â€Â  The trial court allowed the amendment.
On appeal, the defendant 
  argued that an aggravating circumstance is a required element of first degree 
  burglary, and the aggravating circumstance upon which his burglary conviction 
  was based had never been presented to the grand jury.Â  Therefore, he claimed, 
  the amendment to the indictment deprived the trial court of subject matter jurisdiction 
  over the burglary charge.Â  The Supreme Court agreed and held:

The offense of first degree burglary, as defined 
  by section 16-11-311, occurs when a person enters a dwelling without consent, 
  with intent to commit a crime in the dwelling, and an aggravating circumstance 
  is present.Â  Without an aggravating circumstance, the crime committed would 
  be second degree burglary.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-312(A).Â  Thus, 
  although it is only one element of the crime, the aggravating circumstance is 
  â€œthe essenceâ€ of first degree burglary.Â  [State v.] Sowell, 85 S.C. at 
  284, 67 S.E. at 318.Â  Moreover, these aggravating circumstances are quite distinct 
  from one another, and thus, the proof required for each aggravating circumstance 
  is materially different from one another.Â  Compare S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-311(A)(1), 
  (2) & (3).
We find that by changing the aggravating circumstance 
  from entering during the darkness to causing physical injury, the amendment 
  to the indictment â€œsubstituted an entirely different [offense] for the one charged.â€Â  
  Sowell, 85 S.C. at 284, 67 S.E. at 318.Â  The amendment was a material 
  change which modified what the defendant was â€œcalled upon to answer.â€Â  Browning 
  [v. State], 320 S.C. at 368, 465 S.E.2d at 359.Â  Accordingly, the amendment 
  deprived the circuit court of subject matter jurisdiction over the burglary 
  charge.
The State argues that the amendment was properly 
  permitted because it came as no â€œsurpriseâ€ to appellant.Â  The trial court utilized 
  a similar â€œprejudiceâ€ analysis when it allowed the amendment.Â  However, in testing 
  the sufficiency of an indictment and the propriety of amending an indictment, 
  it is improper to look to other indictments, even if those indictments relate 
  to the same course of conduct.Â  A subject matter jurisdiction analysis is performed 
  on individual charges, not the charges in the aggregate. Â The appropriate analysis 
  is whether the amendment to the indictment changed the nature of the offense 
  charged, not whether the amendment in any way surprised or prejudiced appellant.Â  
  See Â§ 17-19-100.Â  We hold the amendment here violated section 17-19-100.

Lynch, 344 S.C. at 640-41, 545 
  S.E.2d at 514 (footnote omitted).
Similarly, the amendment 
  in the instant case changed the nature of the offense charged.Â  The two aggravating 
  circumstances in the case sub judice are distinct from one another, 
  and thus, the proof required for each aggravating circumstance is materially 
  different from the other.Â  The amendment was a material change which modified 
  what Guthrie was called upon to answer.Â  It was impossible for Guthrie to prepare 
  a defense to the additional factor regarding two or more prior convictions where 
  the aggravating circumstance was not added until trial.Â  We rule the amendment 
  deprived the Circuit Court of subject matter jurisdiction over the first degree 
  burglary charge.
The dissent articulates 
  an amendment rule with no boundaries or parameters.Â  The rule set forth in the 
  dissenting opinion allows for â€œamendment ambushâ€ on the eve of trial.Â  Moreover, 
  under the rule advanced by the dissent, a multi-faceted criminal charge containing 
  alternative grounds for aggravation is thrust upon a defendant at trial with 
  an indictment containing only one of the alternatives.Â  The implementation of 
  such an amendment procedure would create evidentiary conundrums of gargantuan 
  proportion to a defendant as the trial commences.
CONCLUSION
The Circuit Court erred in granting the Stateâ€™s 
  motion to amend the indictment at trial to include as an additional aggravating 
  factor Guthrieâ€™s conviction of two or more prior burglaries.Â  Accordingly, the 
  Circuit Courtâ€™s decision to grant the amendment to the indictment is
REVERSED.
CONNOR, J., concurs.
STILWELL, J., dissents 
  in a separate opinion.
STILWELL, J. 
  (dissenting):Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Because I believe the trial court 
  retained subject matter jurisdiction following the amendment of Guthrieâ€™s burglary 
  indictment, I respectfully dissent. 
In Lynch, our supreme 
  court held that by â€œchanging the aggravating circumstance from entering during 
  the darkness to causing physical injury, the amendment to the indictment â€˜substituted 
  an entirely different [offense] for the one charged.â€™â€Â  State v. Lynch, 
  344 S.C. 635, 640-41, 545 S.E.2d 511, 514 (2001) (quoting State v. Sowell, 
  85 S.C. 278, 284, 67 S.E. 316, 318 (1910)) (alteration in original).Â  Thus the 
  court held the substitution of one aggravating factor for another divested the 
  trial court of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  Unlike Lynch, the amendment 
  here did not substitute one aggravating circumstance for another; it 
  added an additional one.
Subject matter jurisdiction is the power of a court 
  to â€œhear and determine cases of the general class to which the proceedings in 
  question belong.â€Â  Brown v. Evatt, 322 S.C. 189, 193, 470 S.E.2d 848, 
  850 (1996); Dove v. Gold Kist, Inc., 314 S.C. 235, 237-38, 442 S.E.2d 
  598, 600 (1994).Â  While the amendment may have offended the law in some other 
  particular, the only issue before us is subject matter jurisdiction.Â  See 
  Rule 208(b)(1)(B), SCACR (â€œOrdinarily, no point will be considered which is 
  not set forth in the statement of the issues on appeal.â€).Â  In my view, because 
  the aggravating circumstance passed upon by the grand jury remained in the indictment, 
  the trial court retained subject matter jurisdiction and the addition of another 
  aggravating factor did not divest the trial court of that jurisdiction.Â  Cf. 
  State v. White, 338 S.C. 56, 525 S.E.2d 261 (Ct. App. 1999).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Marolyn L. Baril,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Aiken Regional Medical Centers,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Rodney A. Peeples, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3561
Heard October 8, 2002 â€“ Filed October 
  28, 2002

REVERSED and REMANDED


  
    
      
Herbert W. Louthian, Sr., and Deborah R.J. Shupe, both 
  of Columbia, for Appellant.
         
        
Richard J. Morgan and Reginald W. Belcher, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Marolyn L. Baril appeals the Circuit 
  Courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment to Aiken Regional Medical Centers (Hospital) 
  on Barilâ€™s action for breach of employment contract.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Baril joined Hospitalâ€™s nursing staff in 1986.Â  She 
  earned a masterâ€™s degree in nursing administration from the University of South 
  Carolina in 1990.Â  The following year, Baril was named director of Hospitalâ€™s 
  emergency department.Â  Baril resigned from that position for personal reasons 
  in 1992, but continued as a staff nurse in the emergency department.Â  Holly 
  Martinez de Andino eventually succeeded Baril as director of Hospitalâ€™s emergency 
  department.Â  John Arnold [1]  and Martinez de 
  Andino indirectly supervised Baril.
In early 1993, Baril began teaching nursing classes 
  on a part-time basis at the University of South Carolinaâ€™s Aiken campus (USC-Aiken).Â  
  She joined the faculty on a full-time basis later that year.
Baril received an â€œAssociate Handbookâ€ from Hospital 
  in May of 1997.Â  She signed an acknowledgment form provided by Hospital, indicating 
  she would familiarize herself with the handbook and that she understood the 
  handbook â€œconstitute[d] the personnel policies of [Hospital] and that [she was] 
  governed by them.â€Â  The handbook and acknowledgment form contained disclaimer 
  language:
Please Read!
Important Employment Information

The information contained in this booklet is designed to 
  serve only as a reference to Aiken Regional Medical Centers policies and procedures.Â  
  Aiken Regional Medical Centers reserves the right to amend this guide as necessary 
  at any time, with or without prior notice.Â  Current hospital policies and procedures 
  will apply in all cases.
Please remember that this booklet does not constitute 
  a contract between you and Aiken Regional Medical Centers.Â  Employment at 
  Aiken Regional Medical Centers is on a voluntary basis and either you or 
  the Facility may terminate this employment relationship at any time with or 
  without reason or prior notice.
No associate of Aiken Regional Medical Centers has the right 
  to make verbal promises or commitments which may create a contract and thereby 
  alter the â€œemployment at willâ€ relationship.

(Emphasis added).Â  Additionally, the handbookâ€™s â€œRecruiting and Hiringâ€ section 
  included similar language:

In no event shall a hiring of an associate be considered 
  as creating a contractual [re]lationship between the associate and the Facility; 
  and, unless otherwise provided in writing, such relationship shall be defined 
  as â€œemployment at will,â€ where either party may dissolve the relationship.Â  
  (Emphasis added).

However, the acknowledgment form states that â€œthe information in [the] handbook 
  is subject to change/revisionâ€ and â€œany change will be communicated through 
  the usual channels.â€
The handbook incorporated a detailed, progressive disciplinary procedure.Â  
  Two categories of offenses were specifically identified.Â  The categories were 
  bifurcated: (1) actions meriting immediate termination; and (2) actions warranting 
  termination for continuous violations.
In July of 1998, Martinez de Andino disciplined Baril for allegedly 
  slamming a door in Arnoldâ€™s face and disagreeing with Hospitalâ€™s management 
  regarding a management issue. 
  [2] Â  Baril was first suspended and later given a â€œfinalâ€ written 
  warning.Â  Yet, the handbookâ€™s procedure mandated use of a â€œfinalâ€ written warning 
  only after two previous warnings.Â  Baril had not previously been warned or disciplined.
Baril asked Hospital to change her work status from full-time to 
  part-time in November 1998.Â  She continued to teach full-time at USC-Aiken.
Baril initiated a grievance pursuant to Hospital policy.Â  Hospitalâ€™s 
  chief executive officer, Richard H. Satcher, investigated Barilâ€™s complaint 
  and found sufficient cause to purge the disciplinary action from Barilâ€™s employment 
  file.Â  As a condition to purging her employment file, Satcher required Baril 
  and Martinez de Andino to meet with Hospitalâ€™s director of human resources, 
  Richard Lowe, and director of nursing, Mary Ann Angle.Â  The purpose of the meeting 
  was to â€œclarify understandings and expectationsâ€ regarding Baril and Martinez 
  de Andinoâ€™s working relationship.
In January of 1999, Baril met with Martinez de Andino, Lowe, and 
  Angle to discuss problems between Baril and Martinez de Andino.Â  During the 
  meeting, Baril expressed concern that Martinez de Andino had targeted Baril 
  for termination which Martinez de Andino intended to accomplish using the disciplinary 
  procedure.Â  Lowe responded that Hospital had updated pertinent portions of its 
  employee handbook to prevent the disciplinary procedure from being abused to 
  eliminate employees and to ensure that it would only be used to positively impact 
  its employees.
Lowe delivered a copy of the new policy to Baril.Â  Regarding its 
  purpose, the policy stated:

To set standard operating procedures in order to ensure 
  that all associates are fully aware of the conduct expected of them.Â  
  This policy will also ensure fair and consistent treatment to associates 
  if violations of these standards of conduct occur.
This policy is based on the concept of increased severity 
  in disciplining associates who repeatedly violate hospital rules while performing 
  work for the hospital or while on hospital premises.Â  Written counselings are 
  given for initial, minor infractions of rules; if the infractions continue harsher 
  discipline is enforced.Â  However, situations which are so serious that they 
  require immediate stern disciplinary action will not follow a progressive concept.Â  
  [Hospital] reserves the right to administer disciplinary action as it deems 
  appropriate for the circumstances involved.

(Emphasis added).Â  The new policy provided: â€œDiscipline is an instrument for 
  changing unacceptable performance or behavior, and for providing motivation 
  and encouragement for disciplined associates.â€
The new policy described four general categories of disciplinary 
  offenses, ranging in degree of seriousness from greatest (critical offenses) 
  to least (minor offenses).Â  The category of â€œcritical offensesâ€ included actions 
  that constituted â€œserious violations of rules or associate misconduct which 
  justify immediate termination without regard to the associateâ€™s length of service 
  or prior conduct.â€Â  The new policy contained various examples of critical offenses.Â  
  It specified in section 2.2.2 of HR116 that actions of â€œ[d]ishonesty, fraud, 
  theft (regardless of the amount), [or] unauthorized removal of hospital propertyâ€ 
  were examples of critical offenses.
At the end of the meeting, Baril and Martinez de Andino signed a 
  document identifying â€œexpectationsâ€ concerning Barilâ€™s and Hospitalâ€™s obligations 
  to each other.Â  The details of the document consisted of expectations related 
  to performance and communications.
On July 6, 1999, Baril suffered injuries when a cabinet fell on her 
  while at work.Â  She immediately sought treatment for injuries involving muscle 
  strain, subperiosteal hematoma, and an impinged nerve.Â  Baril filed an accident 
  report and claim for Workersâ€™ Compensation benefits at the time of the accident.
Four days after her accident, on July 10, 1999, Baril traveled to 
  Tacoma, Washington, for a vacation.Â  When Baril arrived, she received a telephone 
  message indicating Hospital called her sister in an effort to contact Baril.Â  
  In response, Baril called Hospital on its toll-free number and asked to speak 
  to someone in her department.Â  After a brief conversation with a coworker, Baril 
  asked the coworker to transfer her call to her sisterâ€™s home in Aiken.Â  Baril 
  informed her sister that she had arrived in Washington safely, and asked why 
  Hospital wanted to talk to her.Â  Barilâ€™s sister offered to call Hospital to 
  ask why it had contacted her to try to reach Baril.Â  However, Baril declined 
  her sisterâ€™s offer.
According to telephone company records, the call lasted thirty-two 
  seconds.Â  No evidence exists in the record concerning the cost of the call or 
  whether Hospital sustained any economic loss as a result of the call.
Baril returned from vacation on July 17, 1999.Â  When she reported 
  to work the following day, Baril was told to meet with Arnold and Martinez de 
  Andino.Â  At the meeting, Baril learned that by using Hospitalâ€™s toll-free number 
  for personal use, she violated section 2.2.2 of Hospital Policy HR116, which 
  cites â€œ[d]ishonesty, fraud, theft (regardless of amount), unauthorized removal 
  of hospital property,â€ as â€œcritical offensesâ€ justifying immediate termination.Â  
  Baril offered to pay for the telephone call, but Arnold refused to accept payment 
  and informed her she was being terminated.Â  Baril exited the premises a short 
  time thereafter.
Baril filed this cause of action averring (1) Hospital created a contract of 
  employment between Baril and itself through its written employee handbook, its 
  amendments to the handbook, and its conduct regarding the handbookâ€™s policies, 
  particularly the mandatory language of the disciplinary procedure in HR116 and 
  verbal assurances provided by Lowe during the January 1999 meeting; (2) Hospital 
  breached the contract between Baril and itself by wrongfully terminating her; 
  and (3) Hospital violated S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 41-1-80 (Supp. 2001) by terminating 
  Baril in retaliation for filing a Workersâ€™ Compensation claim.Â  Baril sought 
  $403,508 in actual damages, plus costs and other just and proper relief.
Hospital answered, generally denying Barilâ€™s allegations and claiming it â€œacted 
  in good faithâ€ when dealing with Barilâ€™s discipline and termination.Â  Hospital 
  specifically asserted that Baril was an at-will employee throughout her employment 
  with Hospital, and denied the existence of an employment contract.Â  Hospital 
  further claimed that, even if any employment contract existed, Hospital never 
  breached it and that Barilâ€™s discharge was not wrongful.Â  Hospital cited 
  Barilâ€™s own conduct as the source of â€œany and all of the employment actions 
  that [Hospital] took against [Baril].â€Â  Additionally, Hospital maintained 
  that Baril â€œfailed to meet [Hospitalâ€™s] established work standards, stole [Hospitalâ€™s] 
  time and possibly money when making an impermissible telephone call, and violated 
  at least one of [Hospitalâ€™s] specific written Company policies for which [Hospitalâ€™s] 
  action was a stated remedy of the violation.â€Â  Finally, Hospital contended Baril 
  failed to mitigate any damages she might have sustained.
Hospital moved for summary judgment, arguing no material issues of fact existed 
  and Hospital was entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  The Circuit Court 
  conducted a hearing on the motion and issued an order finding: (1) Hospitalâ€™s 
  policies did not constitute an implied employment contract as a matter of law, 
  even when viewed in the light most favorable to Baril; (2) even if Hospitalâ€™s 
  policies constituted an implied employment contract, Hospitalâ€™s actions did 
  not breach the contract because it acted pursuant to the express terms of the 
  alleged contract and because Barilâ€™s interpretation of the alleged contract 
  was â€œstrained and unreasonable and would have led to absurd consequencesâ€; (3) 
  Hospital did not breach any alleged contract because on the date Hospital terminated 
  Baril it had a â€œreasonable, good faith belief that, pursuant to the language 
  of HR 116, it had sufficient and just cause to terminate [Barilâ€™s] employmentâ€; 
  (4) Baril failed to establish a retaliation claim because she â€œbased this cause 
  of action merely upon her own self-serving, unsupported opinions and the temporal 
  proximity between the filing of her workersâ€™ compensation claim and her termination 
  of employmentâ€; and (5) Baril failed to mitigate her damages because she â€œdid 
  nothing to seek employment or mitigate damages in any way.â€Â  The Circuit Court 
  dismissed all of Barilâ€™s claims with prejudice.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, the appellate court 
  applies the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP: 
  summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material 
  fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Fleming 
  v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 567 S.E.2d 857 (2002); Ferguson v. Charleston 
  Lincoln Mercury, Inc., 349 S.C. 558, 564 S.E.2d 94 (2002).Â  In determining 
  whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all inferences which 
  can reasonably be drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable 
  to the nonmoving party.Â  Faile v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Juvenile Justice, 
  350 S.C. 315, 566 S.E.2d 536 (2002); McNair v. Rainsford, 330 S.C. 332, 
  499 S.E.2d 488 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  If triable issues exist, those issues must 
  go to the jury.Â  Young v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corrections, 333 S.C. 
  714, 511 S.E.2d 413 (Ct. App. 1999).
Summary judgment is not appropriate where further inquiry into the facts of 
  the case is desirable to clarify the application of the law.Â  Vermeer Carolinaâ€™s, 
  Inc. v. Wood/Chuck Chipper Corp., 336 S.C. 53, 518 S.E.2d 301 (Ct. App. 
  1999).Â  All ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising from the evidence 
  must be construed most strongly against the moving party.Â  Bayle v. South 
  Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 344 S.C. 115, 542 S.E.2d 736 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
  Even when there is no dispute as to evidentiary facts, but only as to the conclusions 
  or inferences to be drawn from them, summary judgment should be denied.Â  Hall 
  v. Fedor, 349 S.C. 169, 561 S.E.2d 654 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Moreover, summary 
  judgment is a drastic remedy which should be cautiously invoked so no person 
  will be improperly deprived of a trial of the disputed factual issues.Â  Lanham 
  v. Blue Cross and Blue Shield, 349 S.C. 356, 563 S.E.2d 331 (2002); Trivelas 
  v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 348 S.C. 125, 558 S.E.2d 271 (Ct. App. 
  2001).
ISSUES

  I.                   
   Did the Circuit Court err in granting summary judgment on the issue 
  of whether Hospitalâ€™s written policies and actual practices created an employment 
  contract between the parties?
  II.                
   Did the Circuit Court err in granting summary judgment on the issue 
  of whether Hospitalâ€™s actions in terminating Barilâ€™s employment breached a contract 
  between the parties?
  III.
